We had received our beverages and the bread.  The Italian bread is delicious.  The waiter came and took our order - my friend ordered a pasta dish and I ordered a Caesars salad with chicken. Half an hour later... still no meals.  When we were leaving, that's when our meals came up in the window.  The manager on duty, offered to wrap the meals to go.  We both had to decline.  I don't think her boss would like her to eat her meal at her desk.  I really don't want to eat Caesars salad with chicken after riding the bus to Lakeview.   Today, was 90s and humid..... I but that salad would have really tasted great!!! Lesson learned - if you have not received your meal within 15 minutes... follow up with manager.

After being completely spoiled eating and drinking homemade food and wine while on a 2 1/2 week trip to Italy, upon my return it was important to me to find a 'authentic' Italian restaurant to eat as my first Italian meal back in the States.  After much research, I heard about Volare. While it can never recapture the taste of Italy (sorry you really have to be in Italy to taste it), it did come pretty close with their homemade pasta.  Frankly, if you don't take the opportunity to eat homemade pasta in an Italian restuarant then you do not know what the heck you are doing.  I had the Tortellini with Parma ham and piselli (peas).  Their homemade pasta came pretty "al dente" just the way I had it in Italy (after being in Italy I never realized how many Italian restuarants in the US overcook their pasta).  The tiramisu was definately homemade and also tasted like the homeade ones in Italy.  Prosecco was also a nice. I could come back again to Volare.

Great Italian food! Here's what we ordered: Calamari : : cooked perfectly  Gnocchi with parmasean & prosciutto : : rich creamy sauce & great flavor Chicken Cacciatore : : the best i've ever had Tiramisu : : amazing and on par with our family recipe Reasonable prices, authentic Italian dishes, and great service! The place gets crazy busy, so be sure to make a reservation.

I am not usually a big Italian food fan, but this was fabulous. We got the oysters for an appitizer (which were as big as the ones I would get when I live in Miami. Double thumbs up!) and a crab cake that was on special. Both were amazing! For my entree I got the grilled salmon over sauted spinach. I don't think I could have gotten a piece of salmon that big in a grocery store for the $19 they charge for it. For dessert we split tiramasu, with fruit around it. The perfect ending to a perfect meal. The only complainte would be that it was PACKED, but this just showed how great this place is to have crowds of people waiting on a Monday night!

Let me preface this by saying that I used to LOVE this restaurant. I live nearby and it was one of my favorite neighborhood places. I've never had a bad sit-down experience before, so maybe they're just HORRIBLE at take-out. I know their Osso Buco is fabulous, so I called at 3pm in the afternoon to make sure they had some. You see, I was planning ahead for my boyfriend's birthday surprise. I went in at 6pm and spoke to the guy at the front. He told me that they didn't have that dish, and that basically someone must have given me the wrong information. It wasn't what he said but how he said it. He was extremely distracted, almost as if it was a pain to do a take-out order. He kept looking around, talked to different waiters/people, and then when I asked him for the specials, he wasn't helpful at all. I would say something to him, and he would zone out a bit, and then get back to me with a "what? I wasn't listening." I made an order which would have taken 20 minutes, but when I asked if there was somewhere I could sit to wait, he simply said "I do not have any tables for you."  I was disappointed in the service, but what made it worse was that I used to love and care about this place. I left the restaurant promptly but called back to cancel my order. After asking to speak with someone else at the front desk, he goes "whatever-" and passes the phone on.  Volare.. come on!

The food is really good, but the service is kind of hit or miss. And by service i mostly mean the seating. Its a very popular downtown place, and as such, it is difficult for them to keep their reservation timings. The reservation basically just means "you'll be seated some time tonight", but other than that it doesn't mean much. Its a good place to go to if you are 2-4 people on a weekday, but its definitely not worth the wait on a fri/sat night for food when there are so many unique places in Chicago. Overall, if you know this going in, the food is good and of good quality. I do agree with Tracey V that it is a versatile place.

We ate here on recommendation from a friend from Chicago. It was delicious--seafood & linguini special; cappelini pesto. A very nice rec for a Malbec. The bread was excellent. This is a neighborhood restaurant, not a touristy place. Don't let the surrounding buildings keep you from eating here. Excellent!

Went here after my sons graduation, the place was cozy but not too tight. The service was overall good, the portions large, but the food (only tasted the pasta) was only okay. The pasta had plenty of goodies, I had the seafood pasta with lots of lobster, mussels, salmon, squid, and chilean bass, but the pasta itself was overcooked but most importantly had NO flavor of all of the "goodies", like the 2 never had a chance to sit and meld which is the secret of a good sauce. I tried 3 different pasta''s they all had the same problem, lots of noodles not enough flavor! Not sure what kind of pasta they used, but they sure did not taste or have the texture of a good semolina pasta like De Cecco or Barilla, if I go again I will try something other than pasta.

Delicious Italian. I had the Arrabbiata sauce with Cheese Tortellini which was a very nice combination of cheese and spicy tomato sauce.  I eat a lot of spicy food and this is very mild spicy but packed with flavor. I tried my girlfriends dishes as well. The vodka sauce on ravioli was delicious, i liked mine better tho. And Farfalle-bowtie with the Salmonata, which has salmon chucks in a tomato sauce. I liked this as well, although my girlfriend seemed to just pick at her meal. So if you aren't a big salmon fan, I'd hold back on this dish. We also ordered a side of meatballs which ended up the size of a baseball. They weren't bad, but I've had better.  Dislike: It was very congested and loud. We had five at our table and I think if we had anymore it would have been very difficult to hear. The guy sitting at an adjacent table was so close that it almost felt like he was seated at our table. The servers have to squeeze their way thru the people and tables to serve food, seems a little dangerous. I wonder how many spills have happened here due to people collisions.  So overall food was great but not the most ideal place for big groups. Maybe take-out or simply lunch is the way to go with this place.

Good food, great service, but the wait was awful. We had a reservation, arrived early, and still waited more than 30 minutes. Maybe that's normal for Chicago.  If the wait and crowds are your thing, and you like Italian food, you will like. Appetizers came out fast, and were great. They have an awesome house salad. Everyone in my party was happy with their meal.

Volare is like the perfect little black dress.  It's a versatile classic that never goes out of style. It's homey enough to please your Nonna, romantic for date night, and a vibrant start to a girls' night out. Which is probably why it has become my go-to place in Chicago whenever someone in the group suggests Italian food. It's always a bit noisy, but never so much that you can't hear your dining companions. Besides, the concepts "Italian," "quiet," and "dining" don't really belong in the same sentence anyway. It's unpretentious, comfortable, old school Italian served by well mannered, informed and there-exactly-when-you-need'em waiters.  The only-on-Thursday braciola, veal Teresa and linguine alle vongole pomodoro all received enthusiastic raves on my most recent visit. The wine list is well thought out, and  ranges from the approachable and familiar to the boutique and eclectic. Mark-ups are generally fair, and waiters really do an excellent job recommending and describing wines that complement your meal and suit your tastes, rather than the oft-abused quick upsell opportunity.  Desserts and coffee drinks are no mere afterthought here. Cappuccino is perfectly prepared, with a densely foamy top, served seconds after preparation . (No little artistic designs or frou-fy cookies here, and no heat lost in such trivial dawdling.) Tiramisu (usually uninteresting at best to me) is fluffy, lightly sweet and craveable here -  - - with absolutely no resemblance to the treacly leaden squares or pasty mouth coating goo that I have found at many an establishment that should have known better. To sum it up. Trends come, trends go. Sometimes you want a dining experience to push the boundaries. Other times, you want the culinary equivalent of a dear old friend. Consistent performance, familiar but never boring.  I love you, Volare.

This review is for lunch, as I've never actually been to Volare at any other time of day. Get the "Malloreddus alla Sarda," listed on the menu as "Organic pasta with sausage, mushrooms and peas in a tomato sauce & topped with dry ricotta cheese."  It's made with amazingly textured little pasta, and a generous amount of meat and cheese.  Plus, a full serving is easily two or three meals (though that might be in large part because I stuff myself with the delicious warm bread before every meal). Service is always friendly and attentive, even when it's just two of us ordering half-size lunches of pasta.  It's a great place for a relaxed weekday lunch

Second time my wife and I have been here.  Food is excellent.  Gnocchi with vodka sauce is my wife's favorite in all of Illinois.  Seems like it is garlic and ricotta filled instead of potato.  Whatever it is, it's delicious.  As for the rest of the details, they accept reservations but don't do a great job coming through on time which obviously spills into later slots too.  I would recommend giving yourself extra time.  Tables are PACKED tightly...you'll have to listen to others' conversations and barely hear your own.  Despite this, four stars because the food is that good.

Chicken Parm vodka sauce gnocchi and meatballs were all really good..shrimp was big too..chocolate cake dessert was really good..nice environment even had the games on some fresh tvs..garlic bread was stale but reg bread was real good.. Kind of pricey
Low key, simple, but GREAT food.  Gotta try the risotto.  It's the best in the city.

First of all...make a reservation. Volare is always bangin. I love Volare. It's my kind of place all the way. Good, non-fancy, Italian food in a relaxed setting. Everything about this place makes you feel good. The staff is knowledgeable, helpful, and attentive. The food has just the right amount of flair to make it out of the ordinary while still keeping it at a comfortable level. I had the Chicken Parm....because that's my go-to dish. It was HUGE and delicious. The chicken was tender and the pasta was yum. The sauce was right on as well. When The Olive Garden isn't enough, and Prosecco is too much...Volare is spot on.

Volare does solid, classic Italian food for a reasonable price.  I just got back from a business lunch at Volare and it was a nice environment - not too noisy, four top tables so you're sitting close but not too close, and attentive staff that know when to back off when it's time to get down to talkin'.  I had the shrimp bisque and chicken risotto (without the peas...blech!) and they were decent. There wasn't anything wrong with my food but nothing about it stood out either. Also, we shared the cannoli for dessert, which was three mini cannoli on a plate and drizzled in some type of chocolate buttercream or fudge. The cannoli were decent, but the fudge/buttercream drizzle...oh my mizzle! Good stuff.

I was really excited to eat here after reading so many stellar reviews, and I ordered the gnocchi with arrabiatta sauce based on yelp reviews. However, the gnocchi was disappointing, especially for the price...I paid $15 for what was basically a bowl of dough with some tomato sauce. No meat, no vegetables...nothing.The arrabiatta, while not bad, didn't have any evidence of the pancetta that was promised in the menu's description. Our group also ordered a calamari starter. It wasn't bad, but again--nothing special. To top it off, my date and I both got pretty sick from our meals (he had the chicken parm, with wonderful penne on the side and mediocre, breading-heavy chicken). In all, this place did not live up to my expectations, was not worth the price, and made us sick on top of it all.

Very simple.  Old style Italian restaurant.  Delicious food.  Great portion size.  My buddy had the risotto with chicken and peas.  I had pasta with meat sauce with square flat noodles the name of which escapes me.  Both were awesome!  The plates are full of food.  They do not use garnish or decorate the food.  It comes out quick, tasty, and voluminous.  If you want a fancy Italian place pick another place because this isn't it.  If you get there early there is no wait.  It filled up really fast!  I stayed full for almost 12 hours.  Really want to go back and try the vodka sauce.

Volare was crowded -- the tables are squished together, and it was a busy Saturday night. There are a number of moderate-cost hotels in the area, and there seemed to be a lot of business travelers among the clientele. It was noisy. Service was cordial, but a bit unpolished. Substantial portions of good basic Italian cooking at OK prices. A Volare salad was OK, but too vinegary for my taste. Whitefish piccata was tasty, as was sausage & mushroom risotto. We passed on dessert -- we were stuffed, and the choices were uninspired. Overall, not the place for a regional Italian fine dining adventure, but an OK choice for a good Italian comfort food fix.

FOOD PORN!  As a vegetarian, I've never felt the need to eat meat. But as I saw my friend enjoying his veal risotto, all I wanted to do was finish it for him. That's what Volare does to you.  It exemplifies the vivaciousness of Italy through its flavors and the generosity of the Italian platter through its portion sizes. We started with the Arancini, the Stuffed Eggplant and a bottle of Chianti. Followed it up with the Veal Risotto, Wild Australian Salmon (both specials) and some Gnocchi in Vodka Sauce. I only had the stuffed eggplant & gnocchi, which were heavenly. But everyone else at the table thoroughly enjoyed their meals too.  Service was great too. Nobody bullied us into buying any of their $400 wine bottles, which is always a plus. We left very full and very happy.

After going through all the reviews and hearing positive buzz, I had very high expectations. And that usually means disappointment.  We shared the Gnocchi with vodka sauce, rigatoni with Arrabbiata and Capellini with pesto.   There's nothing fancy about these pasta dishes but even pasta can get screwed up. The pasta and gnocchi were cooked perfectly, the pesto was not swimmiing in olive oil, the Arrabbiata had just the right amount of spice and the vodka sauce was not overly cheesey. We devoured every last bite. The service was impeccable. Our server was attentive without being annoying, the dishes arrived quickly, and the supporting staff kept our water glasses filled and cleared empty plates off without being disruptive. very classy service, very professional. We had a bottle of montepulciano d'abruzzo for a reasonable $32 (on the low end) and while the wine was not stellar, it was solid-  of course there are expensive wines that will appeal to the more discriminating wine connoisseur. The place was kind of loud but where we sat, we could hear each other easily enough.  I want to try dishes that are a bit more complex to see whether 5 stars is worthy but will definitely go back again. Volare was able to back up all high praise.

Kind of off the beaten path in the Loop but, I'm glad I stopped in for a bite.  This is a traditional, authentic Italian restaurant with all the usual staples.  You must try the gnocchi which are a carb-lover's delight.  I also really enjoyed their grilled Insalata di Mare--- so fresh, grilled perfectly, and exploding with sea goodness.  Add lemon and you have a great low cal, low carb small plate to share. I ALWAYS have to get it.  They have a great lunch menu with generous portions if you want to stop in on a long lunch break.  The ambiance is that of your typical old-world Italian joint--- white tablecloths, waitstaff dressed in black & white, classic decor, no frills.  You should come as you are, bring lots of friends, be loud, bring family--- whatever. Anything goes. When it gets warmer, the outdoor covered patio is always popular and full of energy. One of these days, I hope to make it to dessert but for now I'll substitute a couple glasses of  Chianti. If you see me there, maybe we can split a cannoli and compare notes. Ciao. ;)

Holy jeeeez....I can not stop thinking about their gnocchi. Visited downtown over new year's weekend and needed to find a place for saturday evening's dinner.  Had heard good things about volare so decided to give it a try and walked the ten blocks or so despite the freezing winds and i'm sooo glad we did. I ordered the Gnocchi with the Arrabbiata sauce and it was amazing.  The gnocchi here are homemade from ricotta rather than a potato base and i don't think i can ever go back.  They were light but with a decent bite and had a slight tartness from the ricotta that was wonderful.  Mix that with the smoky flavor of the pancetta and I was in heaven. My wife had the linguini al vongole (which she orders at EVERY italian restaurant no matter how much i beg and plead with her to try new things) and she said it was absolutely the best she's ever had.  Wonderful white wine sauce and the clams were tender and not rubbery chunks as they often end up being. Despite gorging ourselves on the entrees, we made sure to save some room for dessert as we had seem many of them passing our table during dinner.  I had the creme caramel which was wonderful and she had the tiramisu which had just the right amount of liquor and was much creamier than the usual variety. Many people have mentioned in reviews that it's a loud restaurant, and while that is partly true, the staff and owners were so friendly and helpful that I wouldn't want it any other way.

The food is awesome.  It's quite loud and cramped though, so if you're looking for a romantic intimate Italian dinner with a date, this probably isn't your place.  If you're looking for authentic Italian dishes made right, then this is your place.  Probably the best Italian food I've had in Chicago.  Carpaccio for an appetizer and the huge and delectable lasagna for the main course is an unbeatable combination.  The lasagna isn't like your Mom's (unless you mom is a really great chef) - I'd check it out.  It's pretty crowded on a Friday or Saturday night, so make reservations.  The price is actually fair for the quality and amount of food you get (plus, the location).  Highly recommended!
Good food, a little pricey for the type of food but enjoyable.

Absolutely delicious Italian food.  The wait is long, the place is loud. It's bustling and busy, and I got bumped into a few times by the waiters.  But who cares when you have such delicious food? I enjoyed both the caprese and volare salads. Light and tasty.  The vodka sauce is a MUST. It's incredible. A friend of mine ordered the Alfredo sauce which was to die for as well. These are creamy, rich sauces...be ready for a heavy meal. The tortellini was rich, the gnocci fluffy, and the rigatoni with mushrooms/vodka sauce was lovely.   I would certainly recommend this place.

I ate here last night with my husband who had a major craving for some raw oysters.  They're only 2 blocks away and with the nice weather we enjoyed the short walk. Ambiance is very warm and welcoming.  It's not a huge place.  But there is a place for everything and everything is in it's place (so to speak).  So the end result is feeling like you dinning in more refined restaurant but not paying the price.  Which in these times is REALLY nice. On to the food.  Straight from the menu: Piatto di Ostriche Crude Half dozen raw oysters... perfection, fresh, the lemon was served wrapped in matching cheese cloth to prevent any seeds from falling in your food and the dollop of horseradish atop the cocktail sauce was much enjoyed. Fritto di Calamari Fried Calamari...I went with the half order and was blown away at how much was on the plate.  Easily a full order at any other establishment.  Absolutely not greasy, breading light, no rubber taste.  I had to take half home. With so many rave reviews on the Gnocchi - ricotta dumpling, I had to try it and it didn't disappoint.  Again huge portion.  I had a carry home for later. Finally the Vongole al Vino Bianco o al Pomodoro Clams in a white wine and garlic or light tomato sauce very fresh.  No fishy smell or taste.  Generous portion of clams.  They have it down.  We were stuffed and happy.  Italian can be the ultimate comfort food and I know we'll be back.  Next time with guests!

A small but solid Italian place just west of Michigan on Grand. Not much else around the neighborhood but this place. My friend had been here several times before and enjoyed it. The resturant was very packed on a Saturday night. It looks bigger than it is from the outside. We waited about 20 minutes after our 6:30 reservation and there is precious little room to wait, unless you get lucky and get a seat at the small bar. So, if you're looking for a place for 8 or more, I'd probably go somewhere else. The atmostphere, however, feels like true Italian with a homey feel to it. Again, the place is small but everyone working there seems genuinely appreciative that you came and is welcoming. I had the chicken vesuvio and my friend had the risotto. Both were very good and I'd get them again. Both had large portions that we could not finish. Overall, a very good dining experience and we would go back.

This place had a really warm feel to it.  Most employees were Italian, and seating was very close to one another creating a family style ambiance.   The fettichini alfredo with shrimp was not too creamy, and the pasta was cooked perfectly.  The hand-made sausage ravioli special was great, and the sauce was killer.  The gnocchi was super soft, fresh and chewy.  My favorite was the risotto in a red butter sauce with sausages green peppers, corn, and diced greens.  Uhhmazing.  My colleagues and I had been working all day so decided to have a late lunch at 4:30 on a Saturday, and when we finished at 5:30, the place was already PACked with a line of people crammed and waiting to stay indoors avoiding the snow. Make reservations in advance.

My party of 3 had reservations but still had to wait a bit before being seated. It was totally worth the wait. I had the gnocchi with the Vongole al Vino Bianco o al Pomodoro sauce and it was DELICIOUS! I think I could say it was the best gnocchi I have ever had. Perfect texture and since the portions were very generous, I had a very nice late night meal for later. It was a very comfy place setting, though it was a bit snug, it had a very warm, family feeling to it. I'd definitely recommend this place, though it may be harder for larger groups.

Party of 10, perhaps that was the problem? Reservation at 8pm, seated HALF-AN-HOUR later... wait outside, because it's too crowded inside? I don't know how many times I heard "any moment now" (to get seated... I wanted to ask "which day?"). Seated "outside" -- cold wind freezing half the party, "sorry heater is already at max" -- "perhaps in another half an hour I could find a table inside" Food was ok, nothing spectacular. Steak overcooked, guess I should've taken the pasta... Never again.
The lasagna and pasta with vodka sauce are scrumptious!  If you are in Chicago, this restaurant is a must.  Great atmosphere and food.  Make a reservation!

Oh HELLO. Mangia bene.  This is how it's done.  Awesome food with no bullsh*t.  Very reasonable. Make a reservation, it will be crowded with people like me who want to eat here every night of the goddamned week.

This place is authentic Italian. That's the one liner for people like me who only read the first line. The restaurant is killer. Great energy and great food. I called ahead and reserved a seat at the bar .. a must because the place was mobbed at 6PM on a Sunday. Destiny, your bartender, is a blur of efficiency, warmth and competence. The diner next to me wondered aloud if she should be made a time-study for multitasking. Caution to owner: she is a literally the beating heart of the place. The food was excellent .. meaning that I literally never touched salt, pepper or cheese although they were literally at my fingertips. I had an unorthodox meal that suited me perfectly .. escarole & sausage (contorni but I had for appetizer), ricotta ravioli and arrabiatta, and carpacciio. Some may say that the food is a bit salty .. again note to owner that the food is FULLY seasoned. I like salt and found that I didn't add one pinch.  Add to this wonderful experience 4 generous scotch and sodas (just a splash) and you get the idea that the place grew on me. Highly recommended. Volare is going to be a go-to spot in my list of got-to spots in the USA.

If you're looking for authentic Italian cuisine, this spot is great!   Their homemade pastas and sauce pairings are phenomenal.  (My personal fav....Gnocchi wih Arabiatta Sauce) It doesn't look like much from the outside but it doesn't have to since the food is so awesome.  Prices are pretty reasonable and the service is consistently great.  It is usually very crowded though and even with a reservation, you may wait for up to 30 minutes...nothing the bar can't fix!
Great Italian restaurant! Everything we ordered (as a group of 6) was amazing and worth getting over and over again.  Make reservations, the place is packed even for a late dinner.

Everytime we wanted to try this place we couldn't get a reservation for that night. So... finally I remembered to call early enough in the day and got reservations for 9pm that night ... the earliest they had. The place was packed. It's always packed, and it's a little tight in the entrance area, but the atmosphere is awesome. The maitre de was so italian it was awesome, so waiting was fine. You can get a drink at the bar while you wait but even that isn't too easy. The good part about all of this is the food. It's worth the wait and crowdedness. The waiter we had was excellent and he immediately noticed I am hopelessly indecisive. He let me pick three things I liked and make it into one meal! Isn't that neat? That's pretty neat. SO - I can't promise your waiter will do the same, but I can promise you everything I tasted was some of the best italian I've had. The italian sausage was excellent.

Just like many already mentioned - the vodka souse and gnocchi are one of the best I ever had. Even my bf who hates gnocchi liked them. We shared the raw oysters and the Ceasar Salad (they split it for us :) for appetizer that were also very good. We made reservations the same day, and once we arrived we were sited right away, no wait. The service was great, quick and attentive. It is a loud place and a bit small,(tables are close to each other, no waiting area, so if you do have to wait for a table - it is tight) but to me it adds to the charm of a true Italian family restaurant. Plus, once you are siting down, and they place the steaming hot gnocchi in front of you, as it melts in your mouth, you are transformed to a peaceful place with angels singing Hallelujah. Well worth it.  If you are hoping for a quiet romantic dinner, I advise to go some where else. But if you want great Italian food with an authentic atmosphere, this is the place to go.  I will definitely be back to try out more dishes.
Great service and foods. But a little bit expensive.

My wife and I had our New Year's Eve dinner here.  Our reservation was for 8pm and we were seated by 8:05pm.  As many reviewers have said, it's a rather loud and tight area, I would definitely agree...it was VERY loud and the space was cramped.  That's all I can say that was a negative for us.  Food was great, prices very reasonable.  I would recommend the arancini as an appetizer, it was great.  Our waitress was very helpful and cheery as well, thought the service was overall great. I will definitely return next time I'm in downtown Chicago as I'm sure this will become a regular stop for my wife and I.  I highly recommend Volare if you're not too concerned with secluded/private dining.

I'm going to give you the tip our waiter gave us... call ahead for reservations and ask when they will have the lamb shank as a special.  He says they do it about once a month and we were lucky enough to randomly come on the night they were serving it.  My dad and I each got it and it was fall-of-the-bone heaven on top of parmesan risotto.  I'm a sucker for risotto.   My mom got the very-raved-about gnocchi with vodka sauce and they were amazing.  I would definitely get these to split amongst the table as an appetizer if you're not going to order it as your meal.  My husband got the filet, which he said was pretty good but no steakhouse filet. Yeah it's loud and close quarters but it never really bothered me.  Or my sometimes easily crab-ified dad who was sitting at the end of the table so his elbow was bumped into occasionally.  The food was THAT good. And the cappuccinos at the end of the meal were perfect also, highly recommended!

Volare is one of our favorite restaurants in Chicago.  While not every dish is awesome, some are really stellar.  Plus, it's affordable, and the ambiance is fun.  We recommend the risotto with chicken (a little rich, but to die for), the chicken parmesan and either the gnocci or the tortellini with tomato vodka sauce.   If you are going for a quiet, romantic evening, this might not be the place to go, but my husband and I love to go because the food's great, the staff is upbeat and friendly, and the ambiance is fun.  We recommend going before or after a movie at the AMC theater nearby. Also, they have awesome delivery through DiningIn - we get it too much.

My wife had vodka gnocchi which she loved. I had a special request off the menu (per my usual at Italian joints) - arabiatta linguine del mare. It was unreal, mounds of seafood (fish, clams, shrimp, calamari) - I think I got 2 take home meals out of it. Great wine and atmosphere, had a table in the corner so we didn't have any gripe with the noisy environment like some do on their reviews.

This place was super cute and I thought it was definitely a good place to take someone on a date.  Food was excellent and the portions were huge!!  The chicken parmigiana was incredible and I had to take half home.  Great prices great service :-)

#1 - Ordered a full Cesar Salad & split it a friend & they plated it for us ... how cute is that? #2 - Yes, the place is a little small but I felt like I was at my families dining room table on Sunday night so ... loved it. #3 - Cute waiter. Sounds good to me.

After reading some of the reviews, I thought, "how small and loud could this place be, seriously??" Um.  It's small.  and IT IS LOUD.  Not to the point where you feel like you are in a Wrigleyville bar, but for being such a nicer, higher end restaurant it's definitely noisy...but the food is so damn good, get over it! I went here on a Saturday night and we had reservations for 8:30; we waited about 30 minutes before we got seated and while we waited we had a drink at the bar...I think I got bumped into about 7 times while waiting, it was pretty cramped...and once we were seated, you are pretty close to the next table.  Peter King (Sports Illustrated) was seated right behind me and I could hear him talking about how he basically loves Brett Favre and insult Da Bears over and over again...that was a bit irritating only because I wanted to throw something at him ;) THE FOOD....THE BEST GNOCCHI I'VE HAD!  Get it with the vodka sauce..amazing..the tortellini with pesto is pretty fantastic as well. I loved their tiramisu...HUGE portions... Great wine list, and the waitress was super friendly, knowledgeable and pretty savvy.   Overall I really enjoyed this place...if you can get over the place being loud and kind of cramped and know that it's not the most romantic ambiance,  the food is worth it...

I recently dined at Volare on a Wednesday night with four other people.  Our reservation was for 6pm and the restaurant was packed the whole time we were there.  Our server was knowlegable and attentive, providing advice on both food and wine. Her advice and suggestions were spot on. Our  meals were delicious; each one of us loved our food and had no regrets about what we ordered.  My sea bass was melt-in-your-mouth delectible.  I also tried the vodka sauce - pretty good, but not the best I've ever had. The meatballs received rave reviews. CONS: The noise level was very loud, so we had to almost yell to make ourselves be heard.  The restaurant was very warm.

If you visit here, go with realistic expectations and you will enjoy it!  My husband and I dined here at a recent Chicago stay. Had reservations and got right in although our table was probably 2 foot wide and there was about 2 feet of space in between each of the other tables next to us. Food was delicious! We shared calamari and a side of meatballs as an appetizer. Good wine selection both by the glass and bottle. He had lasagna (which could have fed two easily) and I had Fettucini with Pesto sauce. Divine!! Service was great although almost to the point of "hovering" (I don't need my water filled each time is goes down by 2 inches). The real main cons were that they pack you in like sardines! This is not the place to do if you are looking for a "stare in your eyes" romantic evening. Heck you could stare into the eyes of the table next to yours just as easily if you sat where we did :-) There was a table near us that had two screaming kids while the parents tried to ignore and eat over them and there also was what I'm assuming was a bachelorette party going on as the girls yipped and "who hoo'd" throughout our meal. So def not a "date night" type of place.   It definitely is loud in there! Perhaps they allow such an environment so as to discourage lingering after your meal.  "Get 'em in and get 'em out"?  They also have no bar so to speak, just a small strip with 4 or 5 seats that were continually packed. We may return again although there are so many awesome places in Chicago we have yet to discover we may not.

5 Stars for the food. 4 Stars for the cramped space and pricey entrees.  Went with my sister and some friends for dinner. The vodka sauce could've had more flavor, though. The pesto and arabiatta sauces were very good. The arabiatta sauce had a spicy kick to it as well. The pastas had great bite to them. We shared a side of meatballs, since none of the pastas came with meat. The meatballs were tasty and felt homemade. Will definity come back, but just for lunch. Oh, and a reservation is definitely necessary (it can easily get packed).

Even if you go to a seemingly authentic Italian bistro, the gnocchi is often times dense, chewy, or granular. Do not want. Because of this I've stopped ordering it even though it's one of my favorite types of pasta. When my boyfriend told me that the vodka gnocchi at Volare was a delicious force to be reckoned with, I knew I had to try it.  Not only was it delicious, it was heavenly. Beautiful little clouds of buttery perfection! Go to Volare just for the gnocchi. All of the other entrees I've had are great as well, but since it's so hard to find good gnocchi you should make a special pilgrimage for this.

First rule of going to Volare - Make a Reservation! We tried going here before a movie at AMC River East and were told the first available table would be at 10pm.  Lesson learned.   So after making a reservation the following week, I was able to experience Volare.  The food is great, but definitely be prepared for a louder, more crowded space.   We had bruschetta to start out with and I had the Chicken Parmesan for my dinner.  The Chicken Parmesan was some of the best that I've had in the city.  My date had a really good pasta dish.  I didn't experience some of the service issues others have.  Our waiter was very attentive and quick to bring drinks/more bread/etc.   The downside is probably the noise and sometimes close quarters.  I think it's all about where you get seated in this place.  On this visit we were up front near the bar and it was loud and congested, but I returned over Thanksgiving, and we were seated near the back, and I found it to be quieter and definitely less congested.   The food is definitely worth it at this spot, but just know what you're getting into before you go.

This low lit majestic Italian order of tables, waiters, and customers was impossibly too crowded for comfort.  Waiters are coming in and out of the kitchen through a crowd and somehow the host found us without a pager, or reservation. The dish of chilled concha and calamari is a great starter here.  Their olive oil and vinegar for dipping held me until I could get a word in or an ear for listening through the business of everything going on around us. It did feel we were cramped up against a wall the way the layout is set up but the servers were patient, and fast.  A friend came later to meet us but there was no room to pull  up a chair for him and he was in the aisle.    Overall the quality of the food was well worth the restaurants awkward crowd conundrum.

Dined here New Year's Eve.  The place was packed but the polished and experienced server treated us like we were the only ones in the place, attentive, detailed, and caring.  The food was terrific and we found the prices to be reasonable.  Can't wait to go again soon!!

The seafood pasta (one of the "specials" of the evening) tasted soapy. When we brought this to the attention of our server, he appeared unphased, clearly not caring how the pasta tasted and giving us no confidence that he would alert the chef or was at all apologetic. We know that it isn't the fault of the server that the pasta was a miss but it is his job to appear concerned when he is given feedback and to try and turn a situation around. It wouldn't have taken much to make things right if he had an ounce of customer service skills. Since he and the manager handled the situation poorly, I will not be returning to Volare. They can have their overpriced, soapy, icky "special" pasta!

If food alone were the sole purpose of a restaurant, I would rate this place with  3 or 4 stars.  However the ambiance created by the extremely loud, awkwardly crowded, and sub-par service were so poor that one can barely focus on the food.  I've been here twice because I wanted to give it a second chance, and because it's the only nice restaurant in walking distance to the AMC on Illinois. The fact that I experienced the same shortcomings both visits makes me think it's more the norm than an exception.  I had reservations for 8:30, and got seated around 9:30. Because the restaurant is the size of a postage stamp and the bar has 4 chairs, there is no place to stand and wait without constantly being in the way.  The waitress lost/forgot to place our order/placed it incorrectly and they brought us the wrong food, then had to replace the correct order largely delaying the meal.  Exacerbating the whole experience was the noise level. I'm not exaggerating when I say you can barely have a conversation.  And on a more obscure note, this is the only Italian restaurant I've ever been to that didn't have fresh grated Parmesan cheese. I asked for some and the waiter pointed to a glass pot on the table. When I opened the top I found powdered kraft "Parmesan cheese." In the context of a mom-and-pop restaurant with paper table cloths, checkered tile floors, and low prices, these things would be wholly excusable. But the problem is Volare tries to be a nice restaurant and has the prices of one: 1 salad, 2 entrees, 1 soft-drink: $61 before tip.  For that price, you should go to Coco Pazzo, La Scarola, or Picolo Sogno, then take a cab to the movies. You'd end up with the same bill. There's a reason this place is nowhere to be seen on Gayot's "Chicago's Best Italian" gayot.com/restaurants/be…

Food is good...don't let the 3-star keep you from enjoying delicious gnocchi and veal. Some of the bread was a bit cold, not to sure why. Maybe it was supposed to be cold?  Service was ok. Nothing special. Prized a bit high for 3-star quality food. That's the worst part.

I friggin' love this place!!!  After having lunch at the one in Lombard about a year ago, I really wanted to try the original location.  Fast forward a year and I find myself in downtown Chicago and looking for a place to eat.  After throwing out suggestion after suggestion to my wife, and being shot down with each one, the light bulb went off....Volare!  She loves that place (a repeat customer) and I really wanted to go back.  The fact that you could walk there from our hotel was a nice bonus too!  Now onto the actual experience:  It's a small, but extremely crowded restaurant. Fortunately we only had to wait about 15 minutes for our table so dealing with the crowds up front by the bar was not that big of a deal.  We started with a specialty salad which consisted of a soft white cheese (like bufalo mozzarella, but a little creamier...forgot the name) over a bed of avocado, prosciutto and mixed greens....AWESOME!  We then split the mista grigliata (grilled seafood...calamari, scallops, octopus and shrimp).  That was also out of this world.  I could have eaten that for an entree.  The balsamic vinegar that this dish was served with was so good.  For our entrees we split the parparadelle  with vodka sause and a veal dish with capers.  Again, both were very good.  The pasta was a little rich, but not worth penalizing them for it.  Our final course was dessert and we opted for the chocolate brownie.  It didn't stand a chance...gone in minutes!!  I cannot wait to return here and try some other stuff off the menu.

We had a wonderful dining experience at Volare's. We were staying at the Intercontinental and were happy to find a quality establishment so close to the hotel (nothing like not walking in the Chicago winter). We called for reservations for a party of 6 around 4:00 on a Monday night during the Christmas shopping peak and were seated promptly when we arrived at 5:30. The waitstaff were friendly and very professional. The food was marvelous.  The restaurant did start filling up pretty quick by 6:00 and was packed by 6:30. Typical Italian seating; they really pack them in there for a festive feeling, albeit a tad bit on the loud side.  All-in-all, a very good dining experience.

I've been here a few times now and each time has been delish!! Good wine menu with reasonably priced wines, the appetizers and salads are enough to start 5 people. Excellent risotto, looove the chicken parmesan and the seafood pasta is divine. Portions are almost obscene but fabulous if you love left overs. Highly recommend reservations as this is a small restaurant and unless you like to eat @ 5 you are guaranteed to wait.
Attentive service allows a three star rating for otherwise lack-luster American gravy Italian.

"Volare" Definitions: 1.  Infinitive verb of "to fly" in Italian 2.  Hit song written by Domenico Modugno, and covered over 100 times by various other artists 3.  Italian restaurant in downtown Chicago that I have passed numerous times, always wanted to try, and decided to have my 4th anniversary dinner The definition most applicable to me is #3, so we made reservations for Sunday at 7PM and braved the cold downtown wind tunnels to finally check this place out.  I didn't realize how small this place was when I walked in.  There was a crowded bar area with about 5 tables and then a sea of people crammed into a smallish dining area towards the back.  The place was bustling with people and more people were flying in by the dozen to try and get seats.  They had a two-top reserved for us in the bar area.  It was fine when the front area wasn't too crowded, but once people started pouring in I became instantly involved in everyone's conversations and it was like I was sharing my meal with everyone who was waiting for a table.  I gave a few nasty stares and people got the hint to move away from our table or at least talk with 6 inch voices.  Once the flow started up again it was much better. They had a great bar and a decent wine list.  Since I drank so much the night before (oops) we skipped on a full bottle of wine and just opted for a glass.  Unfortunately (for my hungover self), but fortunately for other patrons, the glasses are huge and plenty to get you through a meal.   I started out with a half Caesar salad, which was plenty for one person, and ordered orecchiette pasta with arrabbiata sauce (geez, try saying that 5 times fast) and meatballs to top it off.   I love Italian food, but I am not Italian, and am no expert, and cannot judge a place based on how their sauce compares to Grandma's, and I cannot tell you how "fresh" a cheese or food item is because, unless it's bad, I probably can't tell the difference. But I can tell you when it's good.  And it was delicious.  The sauce was spicy (even by my standards) and full of garlic; the meatballs were massive and delicious; the pasta cooked just perfectly; the portion huge!  I thought I'd take a crack at eating a significant amount but food baby set in and I ended up with half of it in a doggy bag.  It tasted just as good 2 days later when I brought it to work for lunch (yes, my co-workers were jealous). Definitely a great place to grab some Italian if you're downtown or if you've seen it so many times and just want to stop in to check out the hype.  I would recommend making a reservation, though.  Also, it may not be the best place to have a romantic dinner, but I suppose you can save the romanticism for afterwards anyway ;)

To begin, we had a wonderful dining experience at Volare!  Though we had a large party (14 people), we were seated 45 minutes after our 8:00 pm reservation.  The place is tiny in comparison to other restaurants in the area, so be prepared to wait for your table.  I started with the Insalata Volare (yum!) - it had fresh vegetables (artichoke, hearts of palm, broccoli), fresh mozzarella and a light Italian vinaigrette.  Perfection.  For the main course, I had Pollo Vesuvio (choice of bone-in or boneless; i ordered boneless) roasted chicken, peas and potatoes.  It was phenomenal.  The sauce was so savory!  My boyfriend got the chicken risotto which of course was outstanding, but its way too rich to eat the entire dish (unless you want to be sick -- tastes like its 95% heavy cream!)   Service was excellent & attentive, though I think our server was assigned to our table only.  After a few bottles of red wine and a Tiramisu Birthday dessert for my friend, I was one happy, well-fed Volare patron!  Highly recommend this place to couples, groups of friends, or older family members.  NOT good for children due to the atmosphere and tight spacing of the tables.  Bon appetit!

I've been here twice now, once for dinner and once just for drinks and dessert. In general, I think this is a nice restaurant - nice atmosphere, good service, decent menu and the food is pretty good - however, I do not really understand why this place is so incredibly popular and crowded all the time. As a result, you feel rushed most of your dinner - I wouldn't recommend it if you're looking for a quiet, romantic, intimate meal.  What it IS perfect for is late night drinks and dessert at the bar, which is awesome - this was a surprise to me, as it is a tiny little bar, but the bartenders are absolutely lovely and very friendly and bubbly and there is always a lively crowd there. Kudos to the lovely bartenders :-)

AMAZING....EVERYTIME...PERIOD....I go as often as I can, I love this place. The service and food are top notch, I really can't say much more. Ohhh just prepare yourself for a loud, crazy experience it isn't a quiet environment to say the least, but nonetheless awesome.

This place has always been a mythical restaurant for me because of the wait. I tried going to to Volare a few times in the past, and each time I'd walk up to the podium prepared to wait only to be hit with an hour or 2 wait. I mean I'm down for a good wait, but I'd prefer not to die of hunger so I usually bail before I ever get seated. This time I was determined though. My date for the night wouldn't be ready for awhile, so I got there early, put in my name, got my hour and a half wait time and hit the town. I now know the area like the back of my hand. Eventually I met my date, we went to the podium and they seated us. Perfect timing. Once you are actually seated, you really see how small this place is. Its basically just one room where they fit a few tables and a bar. There's also an outside area out front that accounts for probably a third of the total seating. I wonder what happens in the winter...? Anyways, we were seated and had a look at the menu. It was actually a lot cheaper than I was expecting. Both of us had looked online about what to get and the gnocchi with vodka sauce seemed like a big hit. I didn't want us to get the same thing though, and I love pesto, so i had the waitress choose between the two for me. She said I should definitely get the vodka sauce. So, that's how we ended up getting the exact same meal. I did add some chicken to my dish though to mix it up a bit. I also had the waitress choose a couple of glasses of wine for us. The food was very good. First and foremost, she was right, the vodka sauce was the way to go. Very good sauce. The gnocchi was great also. I've never had such fluffy, pillowy gnocchi before. I ate my entire bowl, unfortunately, which meant no left overs. I think I'll be back sometime, I don't know when though. The wait is just such a pain in the ass. I wonder if I can do takeout...

I was in Chicago visiting my family. After spending the day at Shedd Aquarium, we were all starving. We were going to go to Shaw's Crab House, but with 9 people, it's not a very group-friendly place. We asked the valet at The Conrad Hotel where would be a good local restaurant to eat. He recommended Volare. Great job, valet!  They set up a few tables for us in the heated, enclosed patio area. It was nice and quiet as we were the only customers in there. We ordered minestrone soup and a variety of pastas. Here's a run-down of our meals: Fettucine Alfredo Spaghetti w/ Marinara Chicken Parmesan 4 Cheese & Chicken Risotto Gnocchi w/ Vodka sauce Homemade Pappardelle with Bolognese Lasagna Linguine with Pesto Sauce (my dad added 3 shrimp to it) We also ordered a few spinach side dishes. For the 8 of us (my 4 year-old nephew slept through dinner and didn't eat anything), our bill was $175... just over $200 with a tip.  My homemade pappardelle was so fresh. The bolognese was flavorful. My other nephew (9 year-old) cleaned his plate of spaghetti & marinara. He kept saying how good it was. My brother ate all of his lasagna. I almost cleaned my plate. Everyone else had leftovers to bring home with them. I don't think I was in the mood for Italian, but was quickly convinced. The food was fantastic.

I was only in town for an evening so I can't compare this place to other Italian joints in the area, only to other places I've been. I'd say, for the atmosphere and the price, Volare is above average. Linens and service resemble a fine dining establishment, but the prices and dress code resemble a casual dining restaurant. In any case, we walked here from Millenium Park, which is only .5 miles away but it was freezing so we arrived hungry and excited to be warm. We both got wine, which was generously poured and with good selection. For my dinner, I got homemade cheese tortellini with arriabatta sauce and added meatballs. It was excellent and a generous portion. The meatballs were huge while still being perfectly cooked, light and fluffy. We had a pleasant dinner and if I lived nearby, I'd probably eat here again.
A little loud, a little crowded, but what you would expect of an Italian restaurant?  We really enjoyed our entrees, but we enjoyed watching the big and small groups even more.

I'd like to start by saying you should make a reservation for Saturday night. I'm lucky I thought ahead, the place was packed! The wait wasn't too long, and my friend and I were seated near the middle of the bar area. I ordered a splendid glass of Chilean pinot noir to start the meal. In terms of appetizers, their free bread is pretty tasty. We ordered the eggplants stuffed with ricotta cheese and they were okay. My friend had a some specialty salad, which tasted pretty standard fair. My friend ordered orecchiette with pesto sauce, and I'd have to say the sauce was pretty strong on the basil. I ordered the risotto with italian sausage and tomato, which turned out pretty decently. I enjoyed the sausage more than the risotto, which is kind of disappointing, but it certainly wasn't bad. Our server was wonderfully friendly and generally aware. The food came out reasonably fast, considering the large crowd. I'd come here again and order something different in hopes the food will be more outstanding.

Went there at non-peak time in the afternoon. Food was very good. All four of us enjoyed our meals. Because it was slow we camped out at our table and talked for over an hour after we ate. Staff did not seem to mind which was nice. During our meal the service was very attentive. I would recommend this place and eat here again.

Yes, Volare can be very crowded, and loud, but the food is amazing. We've been here a few times, and have never been disappointed. The service is extremely attentive, and the homemade pastas are delicious. If possible, ask to sit out on the (heated) patio. It's much quieter and still a very enjoyable experience.

I think their pasta is great. We made the mistake of ordering the special which was pizza. It was basically fresh tomatoes on crispy flatbtead and melted cheese on top. It was averge at best. I had the seafood salad with balsamic vinegr which was a huge salad for just an appetizer. The spaghetti and meatballs is pretty impressive and their penne with vodka sauce is good.
Excellent Italiano ...had insalada volare and cappilini w arribiatta sauce...wonderful! I love the outdoor seating too.

Like to plan ahead and make reservations weeks in advance? Check Like to stand in a long line (especially when cold out)? Check Like to not be able to hear your dining partners comments? Check Like packed loud environments that could give one a headache? Check Like slow service because each person is doing so much? Check Like Italian food that won't blow you away but is pretty good? Check Like to pay a pretty penny for your dinner? Check As long as you said 'check' along with me on the list above, go try out Volare. If any of the questions above weren't answered in a definitive 'Yes' or 'Check' - skip trying out Volare!  The food here is good no doubt, but honestly the wait and how amazingly loud this place is both serve as a strong deterrent whenever I consider going back!

Given the yelp reviews I was pretty disappointed.  The Vodka-sauce gnocchi was good, nothing earth shattering.  On the waiter's suggestion we went with the risotto with chicken breast and four cheese sauce.  It was over-cheesy and the flavors were muddled.  You really couldn't taste the chicken.  The dessert was just okay.

I loved this place, it is a true definition of a Chicago resturant. This place has a vibe to it that make you glad you came. It is not a place if you want to have a soft worded conversation with some girl you just met. The food was great, i do not like to eat new things but everything i had wa new to me and i was amazed at what i had been missing out on. Make sure to make a reservation and you will not regret it.

Went to Volare on October 26 2010 and loved it. Believe it or not there are a lot of bad Italian places in Chicago that cater to the tourist. This is not one of those places. This is a locals spot and serves classic American style Italian fare with flare and some leanings of true Italian cooking. Our server was excellent and the word no was not in her vocabulary. Compared to Dallas prices, this spot is not expensive and the wine markups are some of the lowest I have ever seen. This place truly is a find. There are great wines choices in the $35 range. It was packed on Monday night and is quite loud. But the ambiance is real and there is nothing contrived or kitche.  Standouts were gnocchi which was truly hand made as all the pieces were different sizes. We had the vodka cream sauce which was just A-1. The Caesar salad was not over dressed but perfect and the anchovy was not overpowering but just right. Another salad we tried was a beautiful smoked Buffalo mozzy with rocket, parma ham and tomatoes. This thing was amazing.  The entrees were fantastic and perfectly sauced. We had a 2007 Casanova Di Neri Rosso at $50.00, This is a must go.

This place has really fresh ingredients and really good service. My hubby ordered the grilled seafood platter for an appetizer which was really good and fresh. He also got the spaghetti bolognese and I got the gnocchi with marinara sauce. We both loved our meals. We went there for lunch and next time we'll definitely go back for dinner. FYI, we went here after having just returned from a trip to Italy where we had the most wonderful Italian meals so we had to compare Volare to authentic meals in Italy. Volare passed with flying colors!

I work for a huge hotel downtown and I recommend Volare to at least one guest a day.  Hands down my favorite Italian spot in the city.  I'll break it down into three categories: Atmosphere, Service and the FOOD!!  The other reviews might scare you with stories of how small and loud it is.  They are absolutely correct.  The dining area is small and the tables are kind of cramped and yeah, its loud.  It people relaxing, enjoying a bottle of wine and getting loud over a fantastic dinner.  And that is precisely what I love about this place.  Its an elegant atmosphere that is also fun and inviting.  As for the service....impeccable.  Any time I have been my waiter has always been very polite, spot on with the suggestions and a nice conversationalist.  As much as I love the atmosphere and service, the food is what stands out.  The gnocchi with Vodka Sauce is the bees knees.  The sauce is rich and succulent and the gnocchi is cooked to the perfect tenderness.  Whether you are looking for a night out with the Mrs or an evening out with friend for a nice bottle of wine and some appetizers; Volare is great!  I would strongly recommend reservations unless you want to wait until about 930-10:00 for a table.

This is the place I like to take people when they visit from out of town (or the place I tell them about and let them take ME to. ;-) ). Volare serves some of the best authentic Italian food I've ever had stateside. Their pasta is fresh with really flavorful sauces, the calamari is hot and crispy, and the desserts are excellent (I wrote a Quick Tip on my favorites). In short, I have never had a bad meal here. Be warned that the atmosphere is VERY chaotic: the inside is always crowded and it is very noisy. This isn't the place for a first date, unless you can get a table on the patio; otherwise, you'll just be yelling at each other from across the table. The wait staff will bend over backwards to serve you, LITERALLY. They are actually trained on how to maneuver through the crowded tables without spilling a drink or pasta bowl on anyone. I highly recommend this place, but be sure to make reservations first!
Great gnocchi. Light and airy. Super busy. Great atmosphere. Calamari appetizer is well done. Very charming for unique food seekers.

WOW. That is for: 1. How loud this place was 2. How packed this place was (no square inch of floor space was unoccupied by table legs, chair legs or human legs) 3. How amazing the food was. Went here with a medium sized group (8 of us) to carbo-load the night before the Chicago marathon (props to my friend Caitlin C for Yelping this place and reserving it ahead of time!). We were seated about 15-20 minutes after our 6 pm reservation (about 5 of those minutes being made up by our lateness) and were asked for our drink order promptly. Drinks were brought out not long after (I highly recommend the house Chardonnay - delish!) and we were then able to order what would be, quite possibly, the best Italian restaurant dinner I've ever had.  Right down to the bread and olive oil on the table, this place was just amazing. I could only help but try not to grab another, and another, and another, piece of squishy bread, swirl it into my olive oil - parmigiano concoction and gobble it up.  I got a chicken dish with peas, potatoes and a cream sauce and it was just amazing. Everyone at the table was ogling over it and I was certainly drooling on it. I had to order a side of linguini as the dish didn't come with any pasta.  Everyone else also seemed to enjoy their meals as there certainly was not much in the way of leftovers on the table when we departed. Now, aside from the food.  The waiters were kind of burly, not much finesse to be had with them, but they got the job done. Wait: Make a reservation. Period. Food: A+A+A+mazing Service: Rough around the edges, but gets the job done (kind of like a mafia hit man) Prices: Not cheap, but certainly worth a penny more than you'll pay Atmosphere: LOUD, CRAMPED but fun, you can let loose and relax (think yelling across your table, knocking neighbors with the back of your chair, tiptoeing through tables to get to your own, etc.) I'm trying to remember if my ears were ringing after I left here...if they were it didn't matter because the bliss that was my stomach more than compensated. I would go back and wish there was an Italian place like this in Boston.

My friends and I went out for a late dinner here at 10pm. Well, we stumbled in after having walked for a few miles trying to find something palatable to eat without directions. I'm glad we stumbled into this restaurant! Our server was attentive and made an extra point to have our bread basket always full. We never had to wait long for the next step in the meal process, and everyone was very professional and attentive. I was quite pleased that the staff is  significantly Italian. It lent a genuine feel to that whole scrumptious experience. I ordered a delicious homemade gnocchi with prosciutto and peas in a garlic cream sauce. My mouth still waters when I remember how good it was! My portion was rather large, and I ate every bite.

We LOVED this place, our service and our waiter. We showed up on a Monday night with no reservations. We we there around 8ish and only had to wait like 5 minutes. The place was really full but the waiter said it was slow for them. Other reviews are correct about he heat in here...it was definitely warm, but not so bad on a cool October evening, Our waiter was helpful with the wine selection..and we ended up with one that will definitely get you laid if you are with a date! :) The food was AMAZING. The gnocchi with arriabata and the rigatoni with bolognese...OMG. I haven't had a great bolognese since Italy. Afterwards, our desserts (trio of creme brulee and the brownie with gelato ) holy*&%@  Finally, espresso, served the correct way with the lemon rind. GO EAT HERE. You will not regret it. ps- we are ordering takeout again this evening...

Went in for dinner tonight, I honestly feel like this place is about 2.5 stars but since the other reviews seem kind of inflated I'll settle with 2.  We went into the restaurant and were seated, however, we didn't get any menus.  Some olive oil, parmesan, and plates arrived at the table and also bread in a few moments.  Finally we got menus and a wine list, and about 30 seconds later the waitress came by and asked what we wanted to drink.  I didn't know since I just got the wine list.  So the waitress comes by and asks if we knew what we wanted to drink which I didn't since my wine list was unfortunately missing the wine by the glass page.  Anyways... I eventually got a complete list and ordered a glass of Sauvignon Blanc which was pretty good. The bread was ok.  I had the gnocchi with arrabiata sauce and a side of meatballs.  The gnocchi, arrabiata, and meatballs were not really very good and I was pretty tempted to send them back, but I was in a hurry and didn't have that kind of time so I just ate it.  What my husband got was actually very good it was Panna Prosciutto e Piselli sauce with the pappardelle noodles.  I would got what my husband had for takeout, but based on my food and the overall terrible service (waitress was always absent, very slow coming over initially, also slow with check and again with change) I don't think I would eat in again with all the other great choices in the city.
Great Italian food with terrific service. My go to Italian and easy to get to.

We were in town for my cousin's graduation and the bell boy at the hotel recommended that we go to Volare. We go there a bit late since we were waiting for all of our party to arrive to the hotel from the airport. Our group was 9 adults and 1 child and we arrived close to closing. They were very accommodating and patient with us. The food was delish..delish..delish....! A very authentic feel and taste to every dish. I had the gnocchi in vodka sauce and it was amazing. I definitely recommend Volare because the food is delish and the service is great.

Volare is, hands down, the best Italian restaurant in the city. The food is authentic and reasonably priced. I've never had a bad meal here. The service is excellent - knowledgeable and accommodating. If the weather permits, I highly recommend the outdoor patio. I have never had less than a 5 star experience, and all of the food is outstanding. I'd recommend the Vodka sauce! You may have to wait for a few minutes, as it gets pretty crowded, but it's well worth the wait.
Best italian in the city. I even asked my true blood Italian friends.  The gnocci is the best in the city.  Love the environment, makes my irish soul feel alive!

yum. my hunny and i went here for our anniversary.  i had cappellini with vodka sauce.  it was huge and tasty, but i was not especially wowed. he got some sort of risotto with mushrooms.  ugh, his was AMAZING.  wish i had ordered that instead, it was so good.  in fact, i am craving it now that i am talking about it. good and affordable wine selections. i thought the prices for the food were a little high, but you do get enough for a second meal and anything downtown is not particularly cheap.

Look...I'm sure in Chicago this place is a dime a dozen.  However, being a New Yorker now living in Atlanta, this place makes me miss Italian food.  After all....in Atlanta people thing good Eye-talian marinara gets poured out of a jar. Volare made me feel like I was back in NY.  Old school Italian, a crazy lively atmosphere for a Monday night.  Tables of boisterous older goombas talking with their hands.  People yelling over each other, wait staff hustling.  I love it. My gnocchi was outstanding.  Light, airy, clearly homemade.  These were so good I made myself sick trying to finish it all.  I'm sick and tired of the dense, chewy gnocchi you get down south.  The rice balls were average.  Didn't seem to have a whole lot of flavor. I'm not sure if this is a place you go out of your way for...I'm sure there are plenty of amazing Italian restos to choose from in Chicago.  However...if you are like me and in the tourist district on business....this is a quick walk from the hotels and you could do A LOT worse.
Vodka sauce is amazing (gnocchi with chicken was on point).  Everything about the restaurant is amazing.

Ambiance - 10/10 (Lively and upscale) Service - 10/10 (waiters have an interesting accent :) ) Veggie friendly - 8/10 Food - 8/10 Rotolini di Melanzane is superb. Cheese ravioli with pesto - 9/10 Penne in vodka sauce - 7/10

If I could eat here everyday, I would. However, packing on the pasta pounds isn't allowed.  There is never a shortage of food with Volare. I've never been anywhere than the city location; however, Volare has expanded to the 'burbs for easy access for all! I love that Volare offers specials, antipasto, pastas, etc. and gets creative. Their sauces are authentic and delicious. And while I don't eat a lot of meat, I will eat every bit of the bolognese.  It's a great place for dates and groups; however, I wouldn't see this as a very kid friendly place. They have a beautiful outdoor seating area and it's worth the wait if you can get the seats outside. Come here on an empty tummy and eat your Italian food-lovin' heart out!
This is the best itallian restaurant that I have ever eaten at. The service and the food was amazing. If you are near downtown, you need to try this place.

Thank you yelpers for helping me find this place tonight. I'm in Chicago for the week and was in the area and pulled up Yelp on my phone and thought Italian sounds good.  Volare was packed and it was a Sunday night (the bartender says it's packed every night). I sat at the bar doing the single dinning thing. It's a small bar and I sat next to a guy that comes to Chicago every year for a conference and has been coming to Volare for the last 10 years. I had the veal parmigiana and it comes with a side of pasta and red sauce. It was rich and very tasty. I have had thinner more tender veal but it was pretty good and the cheese was very smooth and mouth watering. The red sauce doesn't beat my husbands but it is right up there especially with fresh parmesan.

Tasty Italian food, but not the best I've had in Chicago. The seating is quite intimate as the dining area is small.  They also have a covered outdoor seating area that's nice during the summertime.  Their risotto volare and fattori (although pretty rich)  are my favorite things to order, and a must to try if coming for the first time.

Good, but not great.  I only gave it 3 stars because I think the service needs some work.  I went to lunch with a friend.  The waitress was very nice and greeted us right away, took our drink order and was back with the drinks  right away.  However, once we ordered she was MIA, didn't check to see if we liked our entrees and pretty much ignore my three attempts to get the bill.  She was nice, just not attentive.  The food was very good, but slow to come out.  I would come back, but I don't consider this one of my favorite Italian restaurants in town. On the plus side, the location is good and it's really easy to get a cab when you're ready to leave.

Ahhh mah godddd. Went back to Volare last night after my husband ran in the Chicago Triathalon (OMFG). After him running/biking/swimming all day and me being an active spectator all day, we needed some srs bsns carbs. I felt like I got sunstroke during the day (just kidding...but no, seriously, it was hot), and I started off with a greyhound. Nice and strong. We sat down and the waiter was super attentive and went over all the delicious sounding specials with us. When I was looking over the menu, I was having a miniature crisis because I was so hungry, and everything looked so good, and I couldn't make a decision. Our group started with the baked clams and the calamari. Beautiful on both counts. The baked clams came with these out of this WORLD lentils, which really brought out a lot of flavor. The calamari were hot and crispy - very satisfying stuff. All of this food was gone in about 2.5 seconds. My friend and I ordered a half a bottle of white wine and dug in.  For the main course, I had the gnocchi with vodka sauce. In my (slightly) inebriated state, I described them as "eating clouds". I still stand by that statement - light, fluffy, cheezy gnocchi with a creamy vodka sauce made me almost die of happiness. It was exactly what I wanted.  For dessert, we ordered a smorgasbord of options. Tiramisu, cannollis, lemon sorbet and a cheese plate. My favorite was probably the tiramisu. It had a sexy, intense coffee/chocolate flavor, but was light as air. Everything else was great as well. God, I am glad I don't work next door to this place because I would spend all my money here. Jesus Christ. But yes, I will go back every chance I get, fo' sho.

Went here on a friday afternoon around 1:30 and it was pretty empty, for some reason there was also no A/C, just fans. Good thing it wasn't so hot outside!  First things first, I had the pasta with Italian sausage, tomato, green peas and dry ricotta. It was very good, minus the frozen peas, which seemed to detract from the flow of the dish. The super buttery bread they give you is awesome. For food, they deserve a 4. For service, I give a 2. Despite the empty restaurant the waiter took a long time to take my order and was so impatient, he didn't allow me to finish my sentences. The olive oil bottle on my table had a broken top and spilled all over. When I attempted to tell the waiter, mid explanation he turns away, switches the bottle with another and walks off, not apologizing or offering a replacement for my oily napkin!  Not sure if this was a fluke experience or what, but I'm not in a rush to get back to find out.

Friends brought me here for dinner while I was in Chicago for the weekend.  My one request was that we go to a good Italian place for dinner one night. We had reservations, and even though we got there on time, we had to wait at the bar for about 25 minutes.  Fine with me...it gave us a chance to have a drink, I guess.  It was obviously a very busy place, so I was anticipating some great food. We were so hungry that when they brought the bread after we were seated, it was gone in about 2 minutes flat.  I liked that they had all the ingredients to make your own bread dipping sauce on the table.   I ordered the fettucini alfredo and it was delicious!  Creamy, lots of sauce, and perfectly cooked noodles.   I was a little disappointed with the service.  They were preparing for a large party next to us and managers and servers were busy preparing several tables for it the entire time we were there.  I don't know if it was because of the large party, but our table was so close to the tables around it that the waiters kept bumping into our chairs, which was annoying. We also never really saw our waiter.  In fact, we asked for more bread FOUR times...once from our waiter before our food came, twice from bussers/water fillers, and once from a manager...and didn't get it until we were done eating.   The food was great, but it's too bad the service sucked.

This restaurant was horrible.  It was the worst experience I have ever had dining.  My husband and I dine out almost nightly in Chicago and on a Monday night, we decided to try Volare because it was billed as "fine dining."  It was the opposite of fine dining.  In fact., I find the inside of McDonalds and Popeyes to be more comfortable, welcoming, and classy.   While the restaurant was packed, we were seated quickly.  It was so loud in there, that we could not hear ourselves think and we certainly could not hold a conversation.  A waitress appeared at our table after 10 minutes and gave us our menu.  Another 10 minutes later, she took our order.  We ordered a bottle of wine, dinner salads, risotto and veal.  The wine came relatively quickly, but the waitress was in a massive hurry.  She popped the cork while looking around the room, splashed some wine in the glass and quickly hustled off.  We did not see her again until we walked out over an hour later and she reported us to the manager for skipping out on our tab.  But I am getting ahead of myself.   While we drank our wine and watched the detritus roam about the filthy room in their beachwear, we anxiously awaited our salad.  They brought my salad, which I slowly ate and then pushed to the edge of the table.  A bus boy picked up the plate, and that was the last visit we received from any waitstaff.  We waited over an hour for our entrees and the waitress never so much as stopped by to update us or thank us for our patience.  We just sat there downing our wine on relatively empty stomachs.  My husband and I could not take much more.  So, after an hour without so much as even an acknowledgement while sitting in a small room which was noisier and more uncomfortable than an airport gate at Christmas time, we left $60 on the table and walked out.  Well, wouldn't you know it, our "attentive" waitress noticed us then and she had her slimy manager chase us out into the street to confront us for walking out on the tab.  He called us thieves.  I am a lawyer and my husband is a doctor.  We do not need to steal cheap food.  We did not even get any food.  We told him that we left money on the table and his attitude was like "ok, sorry, bye."  That is was set us off.  He did not apologize.  He did not ask us why we left or what he could do to make it better.  We would have had a better and more satisfying meal off of a hot dog cart.   In short, do not go there if you like to be comfortable, want to hear and converse with your dinner companion, and want polite and reasonably attentive service.  The place is a dump.

OMG!! So frickin' good!!! The place doesn't look too exciting from the outside but the food is really good. I had the gnocchi and it was like heaven on a plate. The portion was huge but I ate all of it because I simply couldn't stop.  One great thing about Volare is that you can order any pasta they have with any sauce you want. Most Italian restaurants only offer a specific sauce with each particular pasta. At Volare you choose the pasta you want and then the sauce you want on it. Sweet! I'll be back...

2nd time at Volare, and I can't get enough of their Vodka Sauce!  Love this spot, it is easy to unwind after a long day here, the bartenders are top notch, and make a great drink, and the waitstaff is on their game, water glasses always filled, etc.  The handmade pastas are also wonderful, but the vodka sauce, ohhh sooo good!  The wine list is pretty big, has nice bottles at many price points as well.  Dessert however, canoli, were gross, luckly only $4, but a waste, not yummy.  Still, i can't wait to get back to Chicago to enjoy again.

My husband and I have been living in the city for more than 8 years and we have had our fair share of great and amazing dinner experiences in the city.  Last weekend we decided to try an Italian place and we had heard about Volare and thought we would give it a try.  We made a 6:30 reservation and despite that when we got there a table was not ready and people who came in as walk-ins after us were seated first.   As soon as we walked in i noticed that it was EXTREMELY LOUD and that was only exacerbated by when we actually sat down in the dining room area.  I don't generally have an issue with loud places but it felt like I was in a sports bar on game day.  Luckily neither my husband nor I had bad breath and didn't mind talking in each other's face!
