  My husband ordered the cheese and meat appetizer (what I call it, I'm sure it has a better title) which he said was good (nothing fantastic).  It took a long time to get him a refill on his glass of wine and we had to flag the waitress down whenever we wanted something as she was not very attentive.  We ordered our dinner about a half hour after we sat down.  A half hour later no dinner and all we ordered was a risotto and a seafood pasta, nothing difficult.  the waitress never came by to check on our food order or to see if we had received our food.  We noticed people who had sat down after us ordering dessert.  We tried to be patient.  After ONE HOUR from when we ordered our dinner, we finally flagged down our waitress and asked her what was going on.  She didn't seem to realize that we had been waiting that long and also didn't notice, until we pointed it out to her, that a large table of about 15 to 20 people that sat down long after us, was now getting served their dinner.  She said casually that she would check out what was going on.  We asked for the manager.  It then took a manager and the waitress more than 10 minutes to return to our table (the place is not that big).  We finally got up to leave and the manager finally found us as we were walking out the door.  Turns out that they had a computer glitch that lost three tables orders, which is understandable and we cna't fault them for that.  And the manager was very nice and offered to pay for our whole meal if we waited, we didn't want to wait anymore at that point so he picked up the tab thus far. We can't fault the error b/c stuff like that happens.  However we were not at all pleased with the lack of attentiveness and awareness of the waitress.  She should have noticed after a half hour or maybe 45 minutes that we had no dinner and should have looked into it, at which point she would have discovered that our dinner request was lost in the system. would like to say that we would give this place another try but i doubt we will.  there are many other great italian places in the city, ones that we know are good and reliable and worth the wait.   give it a shot if you want based on the other reviews here, i hope you have better luck than we did.

I had bookmarked this joint ever since we moved to Chicago 5 months ago to check out.  It appeared in a great location, had covered outside seating (which we love) and based on the reviews, appeared of great quality.  We recently went with a friend who was in town and I have to say, I had better at just about every other non-chain Italian restaurant.   We started off with two appetizers: Vongole Gratinate (Baked clams seasoned with italian herbs and spices) and Insalata Caprese (Sliced tomatoes, fresh mozzarella, extra virgin olive oil and fresh basil ).  The clams were ok and the caprese salad was very disappointing.  The mozzarela did not taste like it was top quality.  I've actually had better from the grocery store.  The clams were just annoying to eat and a waste of $$$.  For the main dishes, the wife had this seafood pasta with a spicy marina sauce, which she absolutely loved.  It had scallops, crawfish, shrimp, fish, etc.  My fav is veal piccata and although they didn't have it on the menu, they were able to make it for me.  However, it was also disappointing.  I've had that dish so many times in even less fancier places and it was much better.   As for the service, no good either.  We came for a Friday night dinner so you expect it to be busy but when the waiter brings the wrong wine and takes 15-20 min to locate him among other issues, that's just unacceptable.  We will not be back since there is a plethora of Italian restaurants in the city that I'm sure do a much better job.  Save your time and go elsewhere*.   * Note: So far the best Italian food we we've had has been Tufano's in Vernon Park.

Delicious traditional Italian food in very large portions, served by attentive staff. Not large and always packed; noise level inside is typically very high; you may be shouting at your date all night. The bar is a great place for solo diners to have an entire meal, but if you want a seat (there are only about 10), get there by 7 PM on most nights or you're out of luck. Appears to have one of the hardest working kitchens in the city - you get glimpses of the cooks from the bar seats - and my only question is why they haven't moved somewhere with double the space. Try the 1/2 Volare salad, lasagna, any of the scaloppine dishes - all winners.
Good service. Great food. I had ravioli with meatballs and my bf had chicken parm both were fantastic.  Sauce was great.  Prices were really good too.
Wonderful restaurant. Portions are generous and had the bolognese lasagna one of the best I have had. Would recommend this restaurant when visiting Chicago.

Yummmm!  The chicken parm is delicious.  My lady ordered the ravioli and cleaned her plate (literally).  She was spooning up the extra sauce and eating it after all the solids were gone. Crazy value too.  Bread, salad, entree, soft drink for under $15 per person.

I make it a point to visit Volare when in Chicago. Always fabulous, but I hadn't been here for a few years, so I was kind of disappointed on my most recent visit. We came in about 8:30 on a rainy Sunday night in July and sat outside on the covered patio. Great table and great service as always, but the food wasn't at the same caliber it's been at before. Hubby commented that my shrimp with the red sauce over angel hair had a plastic taste to it like it had been thawed in a plastic bowl. And I thought his lasagna tasted overly salty. Place was packed so they're obviously doing something right. Maybe just not a great night for Volare. No worries. I will be back again next time I'm in Chicagoland!

A traditional Italian in the best sense. Nice atmosphere, sharp but friendly service, good menu with all the classic dishes and tasty tasty food. Yum! The pork with garlic and sage was delicious as was the creme brulee. Don't expect anything innovative, that's not the point of Volare, just really good Italian food, well served. I will be back!

I always saw how packed this place was and wondered if it was just a popular place to go because of the great location, but now I know... It's superb. I loved their Alfredo Pasta, and their service, and the fact that the pasta is perfectly al dente. I am a fan now. It was good food, good ambiance, good times.

Really, Really, Really good...... Get ready for a busy place though - because, I guess, everybody knows this place is great.  The food is very traditional.  Love the fact that you can pick the pasta and pick the sauce.  If you like Italian, you will get your fix at Volare's!   The service there was pretty phenomenal.  Knowing how busy it was in the dining area, and not sure how he did it, our server did not miss a beat.  He seemed to always be right there when we had a question or needed him.   I really hope I can get back to Volare's soon.   This is a real find.

This place already has my vote for one of the best restaurants in the city. Because of this, we decided to use Volare to cater a party for 15-20 people.  They get an A+++. I wasn't really sure what to get and how much to order for this type of event.  I explained the event and all the players, and the staff was very patient, helpful, and knowledgable.  I ended up going with salad, vodka pasta, veal parm, and lasagna.  They delivered early (and sent a manager as well) and the food was piping hot.  It stayed hot throughout the dinner and was just as tasty as in the restaurant.  It was a hit from start to finish! LOVE it.

I went here for dinner on a Thursday night and it was packed!  So make sure you make reservations.  I had a grouper special which was alright, the potatoes and asparagus that came with it, were even better.  The best part, was the focaccia bread and house salad we ordered, I would go back just for those two things and then order pasta as my entree.  The servers were entertaining and kept the wine flowing - always a good thing.  Try it out if you're downtown Chicago looking for a good Italian place.

===========300th review ======================= We were visiting a nearby consulate & on a gorgeous sunny Chicago June day we looked for a local place to eat lunch with over 200 reviews & a solid 4 star Yelp didn't let us down  We  sat outside on a nice covered patio First served was great bread we ordered the   fish special which was swordfish & the  rissoto Special which came with Sausage & along with a glass of NZ Oyster Bay Sauvignon Blanc was a wonderful lunch Service was superb , professional prompt but never intrusive

Started at the bar while waiting on the rest of my party. Manager saw me trying to get to the bar (large group blocking half of it) so he walked over and asked them if I may get through without me even having to say a word. Once my party arrived, we were sat fairly quickly even though we did not have reservations. Waiter was VERY attentive and informative. FOOD WAS EXCELLENT. I had a penne alfredo dish and I heard the lasagna was amazing as well. Not to mention our bread was filled for us immediately and the waters never even got half empty before they were refilled. We have been craving this place again ever since and can't wait to go back.

My trip to Volare last week was HOT!  Literally.   It was my Fiance's graduation, and thanks to Yelp's wonderful filter of "good for groups," we chose Volare to celebrate with our party of seven.  Our reservation was for 6:30 pm and we arrived right on the dot.  The restaurant, indoor and outdoor, was PACKED and we waited about 15-20 mins until they finally sat us in the middle of the packed room, bumping elbows with the three tables surrounding us.  To make matters worse, it was on one of the first 90+ degree days in Chicago and their air conditioner had broke.  So, we sat jammed in, hot food and hot bodies surrounding us for the entire meal.  Even the house fans they brought in didn't make a dent in the heat.  To confirm what other people mentioned, it was LOUD in there because we were so packed in.  Not great for elderly patrons, or people who enjoy chatting in normal tones during dinner.   Perhaps my review could be a bit tainted based on this heat, but I wasn't THAT impressed with the food.  The apps- fried calamari and bruschetta were good-- a nice mix of chewy, salty and crunchy.  For the main course,  I ordered the Farfalle with the Vongole al Vino Bianco (clams with white wine and garlic sauce).  I thought it was dry, because the sauce was so runny that it completely sank to the bottom, missing the pasta, and mixed in with the clam juices.  I didn't detect much garlic at all, and thought for a minute that maybe they forgot to put any sauce on at all.  I will say that the pasta was cooked just right and the plate was loaded with clams. Other orders ranged from the Vodka Sauce and Penne to the Fettuccine and Alfredo Sauce, and everyone seemed happy with their food, but it was SO hard to enjoy in the sweltering heat.  We ate our dessert quickly-- two orders of the decedent vanilla gelato and brownie, and two of the pistachio ice cream, and high-tailed it out of there. I probably won't be back because of all of the delicious Italian choices I have yet to try in the city, but I recommend Volare (as long as their air conditioner is working) for anyone looking for a trendy, loud and good bang-for-your-buck Italian joint near the Mag Mile.

Volare was great, great food and wine, with great service. The only downsides were the atmosphere and a bit of an overly simple menu. I had some of the best arancini I've had in Chicago here - as well as excellent risotto with seafood - their "Risotto Volare". I found that the best things at our table were definitely the specials - I was less impressed with their basic "pick a pasta, pick a sauce" formula, which was all good, but not  exceptional. But it's a mixed bag, because the things that were really good were AMAZING.  On a Friday night (and perhaps this could've been predicted, especially since it was the night after the Blackhawks victory) it was VERY loud. The waitress had to shout to be heard. It made conversation nearly impossible. The problem is that they've put the tables entirely too close together - you can barely walk between them, and are constantly getting bumped by waiters and trays. The noise bleeds between the tables a huge amount.  I don't mind noise - in a restaurant that bills itself as a bustling Italian pasta joint. But Volare bills itself as fine dining, and so the atmosphere is quite incongruous.

ok so once i again i found myself at volare for free and given my last experience i was looking forward to giving them a second chance. over a year has passed and things had time to simmer down. i got the hand made pasta with bolognese sauce. and while it was good it just wasn't great. this place is overrated in my book and there's nothing that's going to change that. i was with some people who had heard about volare from others who raved about the food and they pretty much felt the same way i did. it's good but really who's going to say it was great? i will give another star because this time the food at least had some flavor but not by much. maybe it's just a matter of personal taste and you just have to accept that there are just some places out there that just can't do it for you....
Very good Italian food, outdoor seating that is covered from the weather. Wine prices are moderate too. Good for a date!

We came here on a hellish winter evening. A Wednesday. Somebody in the skies above clearly had it in for us, and a 30 minute drive ended up taking closer to two hours. I ended up having to change the time of the reservation, and we still arrived 15 minutes late. Car was valeted fairly quickly, and we were seated immediately. Our waiter, Jesus (he didn't introduce himself, but his name was on the receipt), descended upon us shortly after we were seated and gave us menus and told us the specials. I asked him if we could be out by a specific time - and made sure he understood we were in a bit of a hurry (having a show to catch at the Chicago Theatre). He told us it wouldn't be a problem. He floated nearby, about 8 feet from our table while we looked at the menus, waiting for us to choose. Normally this would be a little strange, but he was clearly doing this so that our orders would get to the kitchen immediately. Thank you Jesus. You rule. Once we were ready, I motioned to him. He made the grueling journey of about 3 steps and took our orders, then rushed them off to the kitchen. I say rushed - because I swear we had our appetizer in under 5 minutes. No 40 day wait here! They also brought out a bread basket containing a traditional baguette (not really a fan) and some slices of a flat bread - maybe a foccacia. Those were delicious. Next time - more flat bread, less baguette please! Entrees were served pretty much as soon as we finished the appetizer. They weren't quite heavenly, but both were solid. Again - thank you Jesus. You were a night saver! OK - but I think I'm being too positive. People are gonna think I've gone soft. Time to complain. I figured - hey - it's Wednesday - should be quiet, right? NO. Loud. Really loud. Small room + packt like sardines + bad acoustics = shouting. Argh. Men's bathroom was fairly clean, but very sterile (a bit nicer than a stadium bathroom, with ever so slightly nicer toilet paper). My date reports that the lady's bathroom was equipped with one of those fancy toilet seat covers with the sliding plastic covers... and that it didn't work. My entree was pretty good, but not walking on water good. My date's was better, but still not rising from the dead good. So - overall - awesome service, speedy (at least when you ask them to be), mediocre atmosphere, decent food. Amen.

Walking from the theater hungry for grub @6pm on Memorial Day, my friend Mark decided against Bandera to eat here. I wish we'd kept walking.  Once seated inside ----smashed in the corner so close to the wall and the side of the bar that I could barely move my chair----I noticed a smell that could be associated with a dank basement, so we asked to be seated outdoors. I had the calamari (good, but I've had better) and a great salad. Mark had the pasta with a lobster and shrimp alfredo sauce....and it was good. Good conversation, wine and decent food was enjoyed by all....until......the GARBAGE truck pulled into the alley adjacent to the restaurant patio to collect Volares garbage. TOTALLY DISGUSTING SMELL INVADED MY NOSTRILS TAKING OVER THE ENTIRE OUTDOOR PATIO.....and I'm never going back. I almost threw up my entire dinner. You could read the disgust on everyone's face.
Great place to go during lunch hour. No line and fabulous food. My favorites are mediterranean seafood salad and penne arrabiatta.

My family and I were in Chicago last weekend and our hotel recommended we try this place. It was DELICIOUS!! Great service, everyone was friendly and anxious to help out and provide suggestions. I had risotto - it was WONDERFUL, I got to taste everyone elses meals and was very pleased - we all were. Can't wait to go back!!

Went to Volare with friends to celebrate a birthday.  We were encouraged to sit outside in the covered and heated area and despite our hesitation because of the chilly Chicago spring night went ahead. The staff quickly turned down the heaters that were blasting and made us feel  like we were transported from Portofino to the Arizona desert. Our group ordered a variety of entres and were generally pleased.  My salmon grigliato con spinaci was prepared just right (medium rare) and the spinach was sauted with the coorect amount of garlic and not too much olive oil.  Started with the minestrone di verdure alla toscana which was adequate but nothing really special. The dinner ended with a complimentary tiramisu that we found just right after the large portions. Overall, a nice restaurant quite a bit larger than many Italian restaurants-not quite as intimate as Hole-in-the-Wall-but still nice for a centrally located restaurant.

It did not meet expectations.  The ensalata de mare was a 13 buck platter full of a lot of calamari, conch slices and one shrimp.  The dressing was good but overall did not impress.  The clam vongole was good, but once again could have been better.  A little grit in every other mouthful took away the enjoyment.  The ambiance is very very urban.  The wine by the glass we ordered were just OK for the price. Place was hopping on a Monday night so obviously they have their fans.

Definitely come here if you're in the neighborhood--but not the best in town.  Nothing is that great about this place -- the dining room is crowded, the bread is meh, and the wine offerings leave a lot to be desired.  That said, the strength is in the food -- which IS good and reasonably priced.

Never really got to enjoy my food.  I had a major problem with the valet.  When I parked my car near the restaurant and didn't valet, the valet jerk threatened to call the police and have my car towed.  I complained to the manager who couldn't have cared less.  I guess being a paying customer means absolutely nothing, especially true when the restaurant gets kick backs from the valet.  I guess making a couple of extra dollars really helps the restaurant stay in the black. I wont be back!!!

Seriously enjoyed it. I've been walking past this place for years and the appearance of the exterior of the restaurant isn't all that appealing but the food makes up for it.  It's a great place for a business lunch or a casual lunch/dinner with friends. The portions are huge so make sure you arrive with an appetite. For an appetizer you should try the Rotolini di Melanzane (Rolled eggplant stuffed with fresh ricotta cheese, served with pomodoro sauce). YUM!!! You get 4 pieces of that and after the bread and our app, I was already pretty full. For my entree, I had the Risotto Fattoria with diced chicken breast, peas and a four cheese sauce. The portions were insane and it was SO good. It's too bad my appetite was already wearing away from the food I previously ingested.  My friend had the Gnocchi which is also raved about at this place. Our waiter was very friendly but a little bit obsessive with taking our order (and it wasn't even busy). Sometimes it's nice to just chat for a bit and have some wine before getting down to the food business. He was still very nice and attentive.  When the weather is lovely, I'm sure their small outdoor patio is nice to sit on for the views of the highrises surrounding Volare but the decor is a little cheesy.  Overall, I can't wait to go back and try some more delish dishes!

Seriously, AWESOME homemade pastas. The best gnocchi I think I've ever had. But it comes at a price... The place is insanely loud and wayyyyy overpacked. They really cram them in there. The woman behind me COULD NOT CONTROL THE VOLUME OF HER VOICE.

The food was absolutely delicious.  I had had it catered before, but I finally was able to dine-in.   The restaurant was packed when we were there on a Sunday night, a good sign.  We started with the antipasto platter and the usual bread dipped in olive oil with parmesan.  A great start.  I ordered the linguine with clam sauce.  It was sooo good and they were not skimpy on the clams.  I had clams in the sauce and then clams in their shells around the rim of the bowl as well.  Everyone else at the table was pleased as well, some had gnocchi, some had risotto and other various pastas.  And the desserts!  I don't even like dessert and I was in heaven.  The taramisu, oh, so so delicious. The only complaint I have is the terrible service.  Our drinks were never refilled, we were not even asked if we wanted to order until we flagged her down after close to 20 minutes.  She never asked us how everything was and getting dessert and then the bills also took forever.  She was very busy, that is true, but the other tables around us were getting plenty of attention.  I wish i could remember the servers name to be sure not to ask for her again. The food was that good, that I will return and just cross my fingers for better service.

Volare offers excellent pasta, pizza, bread and iced tea (for those of you who are in search of the world's best glass of iced tea).  The Volare salad is solid too.  This place offers a very good, ethnic Italian meal at a fair price very close to the heart of the city-- it won't disappoint for either lunch or dinner.

Nice little place. The noise can sometimes get a little overbearing, but I think it adds to the family atmosphere of the joint. I started off with a Caprese salad. Not bad. Not great either. The calamari was good, but a little too chewy. The bread was ok, but again, nothing overwhelmingly good. For my main course I ordered the gnocchis. They were tasty. Tastier than I expected after eating my appetizer and salad. However, they just weren't anything exceptionally special. Servers, bartenders and other staff here were rude, and most didn't care if you were happy or not. When it comes to Chicago, Volare is definitely not one of the best Italian restaurants around. I would be lying though, if I said it's not worth visiting.

This is a really tasty place. I'm happy to call it my "neighborhood Italian." The fried calamari is consistently outstanding, to the point where a friend told me that nothing on earth makes him happier than taking a box of the calamari home and eating it in front of the tv with a glass of wine and the warm bread they always give so generously with the take out orders. My last birthday's awesomeness was partly to the fact I had their spaghetti bolognese (my favorite food in the world since childhood) for dinner, and leftovers at 4 am after I had rolled back home after a long night of drinking. For those who "read between the lines," yes that paragraph implied two things: 1. MASSIVE pasta/risotto servings. yes an order costs more than you might like but you're really paying for enough food for two, maybe three, meals. Really GOOD meals. 2. they do takeout, which is a lifesaver because the restaurant itself is constantly packed. I've never been inside without there being just so many people and the kitchen's going crazy with the hurry. I've only eaten in the restaurant once or twice. The service is pretty good, but just because I don't like crowds or feeling rushed, then I prefer to eat at home. But the food is so good, so much more than a lot of the other Italian-American big platter places nearby. And they serve until something around 11 pm too, which is great if you're hungry after an evening show at the AMC about a block away. I'd highly recommend this place to anyone who loves a comforting bowl of pasta as much as I do, anyone wanting a respectable place to eat after hitting Michigan Avenue or the movies, or anyone just straight up starving!

A little taste of splendid perfection. I'm so glad I finally went here after passing by numerous time while walking over to the movies.  And boy was I glad I did. The food: its composition & taste, was nothing but spectacular and I loved every bite of it.   I had the House Salad and Scaloppa di Vitello zii Teresa (veal medallion) paired with 2 italian wines I can't remember :) Most portions seems very generous, however my dinner was on the lighter side -- I wish I had 5 medallions of veal instead of the 3 they gave. Every bite was delicious and made me crave more. The only reason I did not give this place a 5 is that I must first experience more and come back a second time.
Gnocchi is super tender and the vodka sauce is perfect.  However its a large portion.  I prefer something with meat so I get osso buco and let my girlfriend get the gnocchi so I can sneak some.  Yum!

Best Italian I have ever had. Vodka sauce, rissotto, and salmon were amazing. Went with friends and everyone ate off each others plates commenting, "This is the best. No this is the best." Our waiter Diego was the coolest. Ask him about his home town in Italy.
I've been eating here on business trips for years. Everything is very good. Their pesto sauce is excellent.

Yes, it is that trendy -- like call at 4PM to score a 9PM reservation for two -- but, oh, it is that GOOD too, and totally worth the wait to eat at an actually good dining establishment vs. the tons of touristy in-and-out factory style places in the neighbourhood. True, the waitstaff aren't particularly friendly -- but once you get over the fact that they aren't trying to be your bff's, service is plenty functional and efficient, and the focus is the food, people! I for one, have lost my heart (wait for it!) to the hearts of palm salad! (ohhhh ouch yes sorry that was bad) No, but seriously -- I'm usually really skeptical of pre-dressed salads and hate when they taste more like dressing than salad. Salads are salads, and not usually the part of the meal I'll rave about, but this was just so perfectly balanced, and a fabulously interesting mix of textures.  Couple in some perfect homemade pastas w/ tasty sauces, and you have me pretty damned happy with my meal. The wine list is great too, although without Quartino's carafe flexibility -- but for overall meal experience, Volare gets my vote!

we went to dinner over the weekend - a group of 8. We had reservations for 9:30 pm but when we got there we had to wait for half an hour and nobody seemed to know exactly when we would actually get our table. They asked us about our plans after - perhaps to determine if they would give us a a table on time? they asked us to wait at the bar area which was small as well with diners on one side and our large group had to stand right beside other diners which made it quite awkward for all of us.  when we were finally seated the waiter came up to one of our friends and told him people have been complaining about how loud he is. The place itself is small and super loud - you can hardly hear anyone at your table so i thought it was a little targeted to come to our friend and complain to just him. At the end of the meal when we were ordering dessert the waiter just stood at our table insisting that we need to make up our minds right that moment till one of us had to ask him to leave and come back until we made up our mind - it wasnt attentive service it was quite abruptive. the food was okay and the seafood rissotto ranked high amongst our group. however, i wont be going back anytime soon given the high price, the poor service and ambiance.

The food and the prices are A+++.  This is just no frills great traditional Italian food.  The ambiance is slightly outdated...definitely not a trendy place at all.  We walked in with a 6:30 reservation on a Sunday and were seated immediately which sounds like we got lucky from reading some of the other reviews.  I dont know what I would have done had we had to wait because I was starving...like to the point where I was about to start gnawing on my hand.   My friend and I ordered the Volare salad, the arancini, gnocchi marinara, and rigatoni alla vodka.  The waitress kindly warned us the portions were large, so she recommended a half salad.  The salad and arancini were both delicious, however the arancini didn't stand a chance against the numerous traditional versions that I sampled throughout Sicily in March of last year.  They were a little small, but very tasty nonetheless.   My friend and I both loved the pastas, although her rigatoni was DROWNED in vodka sauce.  We both had nice little doggie bags to take home...but I doubt I will get to enjoy mine because my boyfriend has already gotten his grubby hands on my gnocchi!   The service was good, but our waitress seemed like she was auditioning for a Broadway show and was a little nutso so that kinda turned me off.  All in all, I love Volare.  It's super cheap -- our meal cost us less than $50 total including tax and tip.  Mind you, we didn't drink because we were both incredibly hungover (maybe that's why I also savored my gnocchi like it was the last meal I would ever eat), but I would imagine that even the wine options would be reasonably priced.   Cute date place, not trendy, food is delicious, service and decor are a bit outdated.  Did I say the food is delicious? Must go....pry....food....out of BF's....hands.

I am not sure why I gave this 4 stars previously, but this is by far my favorite Italian restaraunt in the city. I would just reccomend that if you are going to have a reservation as they do get busy, especially on the weekends. For starters the menu is great. They have a large pasta and sauce variety that you can mix and match and a variety of chicken, veal and beef dishes. I have had the ministrone soup on multiple occassions and it is wonderful, along with the soup of the day. The cesar salad is average, but the tomatoe mozzerlla salad makes up for it. For dinner I have tried the pesto sauce, the aglio y olio (which is the only one that holds a candle to mine), the vodka and the meat sauce and all are amazing. They sauce their pastas perfectly. All of the pastas are great and they have everything from angel hair to gnochi. The service is amazing. My glass is never empty, and when you get up to go the restroom, they refold your napkin. Several staff members including managers stop by to ensure you are having a great experience. As for dessert, the tiramisu and canolli's are wonderful. My mom went there prevously and loved the spumoni gelato. This is just an amazing restaraunt and I plan on returning again and again!

Because the restaurant we wanted to go to was booked until 7:45, my friend and I decided to look into restaurants a little further into the city.  We had wanted to get in pretty quickly and get out also quickly in order to arrive at the Chicago Theater in time for our show.  We ended up choosing Volare based on the good reviews on Yelp.  Getting there was a bit of a task, and we ended up having to bump up our reservation because traffic SUCKED.  They kindly told us they would have a table waiting for us when we arrived, which they did. They also had valet, which most Chicago restaurants do. Life saver.  My friend told our waiter that we were in sort of a rush to get to the theater by 8, and he said that would be no problem, even though it was already 6:45.  We decided if he's right we might as well order an appetizer, we wont be late right? We ordered the bruschetta, which was pretty good.  Obviously a little hard to cut and eat properly, but when you're hungry it's best to just dive into the food.  The waiter brought it to us in a matter of a few minutes.  He definitely listened to our plea.  I was in love with their tomato bread. Not sure why, but it was amazing, and I probably could have eaten the whole basket of bread that night. Both of us ordered Vegetarian meals, pesto tortellini and egg noddles with vodka sauce.  I didn't happen to love either of the dishes, but they also came out relatively quickly compared to everyone else that was dining.  I would say these dishes were really filling, but were also too thick and creamy of sauce and not enough of the flavors I'd have liked.  It just seemed like a standard pesto sauce and vodka sauce with no originality.   Overall the food was OK.  I think the layout of the space isn't really too great.  You're pretty much crammed in and seated next to a bunch of different tables, where you probably can hear a few conversations at once.  Therefore, if you're going for a romantic date, it's probably not the BEST place to be. But, they do listen and are accommodating and I'm sure if I had tried a meat item on the menu I may have liked my dish better, if it was something they specialized in. We got to the Chicago theater with perhaps a minute to spare. So, our waiter did good!

They recommended very good wine against what I ordered, and I liked it much better. I sat outside under the heat lamps and it was still nice. I ordered the chicken parm and it was fantastic. My girlfriend ordered whitefish and she loved it too. The vodka sauce on the pasta was delicious also.

Super crowded and loud.  Went there Sunday night around 6. Made a reservation so we were lucky. Overheard the host tell a party of 2 that their wait would be about 45 minutes. Appeared to be a very popular place for both locals and tourists. No waiting area so everyone's standing around near the bar.    Started off with Fried calamari and Crab cake. Both were decent. Then we got pasta dishes and all three of us were disappointed. We might have had high expectations, but none of the dishes really pleased us.  Because it was so busy, our waiter rarely came by. Actually, the staff generally didn't say much when they did come. Kinda hurriedly did their job and rushed to the next table.  *Avoid sitting near the front door as their phone rings constantly and LOUDLY.
best italian food in the city. family favorite. get the risotto, and the gnocchi with vodka sauce.

I went there for dinner on a sunday night hoping that it wouldn't be too crowded, but I was wrong... The place looked chaotic but the manager, I assume, found me a seat at the bar while I waited for my husband to arrive.  We were seated immediately after my husband came 'cuz we had made reservations. The bread the waiter gave us was the best!! It was so soft and had seasoning on top that was a delight. There was also the unseasoned bread that most Italian restaurants serve.  We had the starter-eggplant-risotto that simply melted in the mouth and was so flavorful!  Even though we're vegetarian, we were able to customize the entree and it was very very tasty. The portions were large and we had to get some it in a box as we couldn't finish it. All in all, a great experience!!

First time eating at Volare, and the food was good. Started off with 3 appetizers and some meatballs.  BTW - was not eating alone, we had a group of 4, more than enough food was served. Antipasto all' Italiana - wonderful!  Who doesn't like a good meat and cheese spread Insalata di Mare - conche...not so good Rotolini di Melanzane - baked eggplant, always a favorite, but even better with stuffed ricotta! Also we ordered a side of meatballs, so tender and juicy, but not enough marinara sauce on the side.  The meatballs didn't really need it though. For dinner, I had the Costolette di Agnello (Grilled Colorado lamb chops in a demi-glace sauce).  Let me tell you, if you are a fan of lamb, this dish pretty amazing.  Don't have to tell you how to eat it, but medium rare is preferred! Not known for the deserts, but you have to get the pistachio gellato, rich and creamy with pieces of pistachio to help end the night! Ambiance is loud and would not recommend it for families with children, but you can't go wrong with the food.

Called for a 8:00 reservation and was told that the best they had was 830.  I thought that would work out really well as we also were going to a 1030 movie nearby.  I allowed plenty of time for a multi course meal.   Had to wait only a little bit for a table, but sat and sat and sat some more until our first food (other than the bread basket) arrived....9:46!   You simply can not have a leisurely paced dinner and get to a show in 45 minutes.   We ate 1/2 our entrees and were offered coffee after 10...I wanted coffee and dessert, but there wasn't any time for it.   I know that they were super busy...and I tried to plan a very enjoyable time.  The staff was friendly, ambiance nice.  Go here if you have lots and lots and lots of time with no where to be afterwards.  Food is good.  Service professional and friendly.

Motto Beno. I think that means i liked it here. This place is great! We went here for a business meeting and were very satisfied with the food, service, and wine. These people go out of their way to please everyone. Ridiculously good food, and truly authentico!!! I'll be coming back here if I'm in Chicago.

Probably one of my favorite places in all of Chicago. Service is first class. Food is very authentic to traditional Italian (as opposed to Chicago Italian). I try to go here as often as possible -especially when friends from out of town are visiting. The manager, Simone, is very accommodating. He even gives me recommendations on other great Italian spots in Chicago! He's been dead on every time. Definitely check this place out!! Make reservations if you are grabbing dinner. Pretty packed at night.

Went here again for lunch almost a year to the date of my last visit. Getting in during lunch was quick and the staff is just so very efficient and friendly. Greetings all around and goodbyes from people who didn't deal with you at all. That's good customer service. Now,  my meal was a little hit and miss however. I have had this obsession with risotto since i've started watching Hell's Kitchen (since they make it every episode) and it was awesome! It was risotto with shrimp and asparagus.  Soooo not sure where the shrimp came from but they tasted as though they were from the Chicago River. Yeah, imagine that for a second. Why didn't I send it back? well it was a business lunch , yada, yada and things are complicated. So very unlike me, but I just pushed the gross shrimp aside and ate the risotto. If you're going to get shrimp be sure to inquire about the freshness and whether or not they are brought in daily from the Chicago River.

We've dined at Volare several times, and we feel our experiences our consistent with the other reviews. Reservations are a must for the weekend, or expect to wait. Atmosphere is buzzing and loud, but not so much you can't enjoy your company and meal. Service has always been top notch! Fun spot to take out of towners!

Omg, left here STUFFED! I really like the relaxed, cozy atmosphere they have going on here, and their food was pretty awesome.  I got the tortellini with the arrabbiata sauce, and my friend and I split a side of their meatballs (those suckers were pretty massive). Despite being completely packed on a Thursday night (we took it as a good sign), we were seated right away.  Well, we did have a reservation... I highly highly recommend making a reservation.  FYI, they do have an enclosed outdoor seating area with heating, but we opted to eat inside. The crowd was a mix of families, after-work diners, out of towners, etc.  I would say a little bit more dressy than plain jeans and a tee, but no need to get crazy decked out (unless you really wanted). Before our entree's came, I pretty much had stuffed myself with their bread =P  I know, I know, stay away from the carbs, but I was hungry!  The bread was warm!  I couldn't resist! To top it all off, they had a nice selection of wines. I am definitely coming back here to try their gnocchi! Om nom nom!

Every time I bring an out of towner to Volare it becomes their favorite and insist on going there when in town again. The Insalata Mediterranea is excellent if you like seafood. The grilled octopus is perfect and never rubbery. Risotto Volare is my favorite entree. And yes, I love sea food. Volare has the feel of a local hole-in-the-wall neighborhood restaurant even though it is one block of Michigan Avenue.

good god this place is delicious.  i visited a friend and she made my man and i reservations. i trust this gal, as she is from italy and her mama is one of the best damn cooks out there. she knows where it's at... it's here. we had caprese salad to start and shared the ricotta gnocci with vodka sauce and the scaloppa di vitello zii teresa. now, in my experience ricotta gnocci is a little more difficult to come by than it's cousin potato gnocci. my gram used to make them with ricotta and they were the best. but i can say in all honesty these were just as unbelievably scrumptious. i only wish i had added the meatballs too. the service was excellent. on my next visit to chicago, i will definitely be back.

Met some friends for dinner there on a Sunday evening.  The place was packed. Our waitress was attentive and food was server promptly. Unfortunately, I got the Risotto Sardini, and I cannot recommend it. It was not a creamy rice concoction, but was more like rice mixed with sauce. It may not have been great, but there was a lot of it. On the other hand, 2 of the people at the table said the Osso Bucco, on special for the night, was superb, and another person enjoyed his lamp chops, so quite possibly I just got the wrong dish. The calamari we had as appetizer was tender and tasty.

I'll say off the bat - we did not eat here. This review is just a eater beware. We walked over here from our hotel and everyone was so rude. The host was rude, the waiters and staff walking around were rude. So rude that we left. I'm sure the food is great and maybe we'll make it back on a less busy night but seriously - don't be so rude b/c you never know who you're dealing with.

Dinner for 4 in the dining room at 9pm. The bread and parmesan cheese were welcomed by my group, and the caprese was good, but not mind blowing. They were skimpy with the balsamic (didn't even have any on the tables). The shrimp cocktail was the best item we got - big, well cleaned shrimp, cooked correctly. The house salad was run of the mill. I had the lobster ravioli (which has asparagus on top) because the waitress said they made it fresh at the restaurant that day. Once the dish arrived and I tasted it, it was clear that the ravioli were not made fresh that day - and were actually store bought and previously frozen. So disappointing! The seafood linguini special, which my friends had, was extremely large in size, but the seafood didn't taste fresh enough for my palate. Especially the clams and mussels. The gnocchi looked good from afar, so maybe I would be reviewing Volare more positively had I ordered that. Overall - I wouldn't order hot seafood here again, and will likely never return.

Enjoyed a casual meal here during a recent trip to Chicago, and I'm glad the hotel concierge recommended this place. Shared a Insalate Volare -- a little overdressed, but a good mix of ingredients and a nice change away from a standard house or Caesar salad.  For dinner, I paired the housemade paperdelle with marinara sauce, and added meatballs. I could only eat one meatball (you get two, and they are huge), and it was moist and delicious. Oodles of sauce and soft noodles made a nice combination with the meatballs. My co-worker had cheese ravioli and said they were great. No room for dessert! Overall, excellent Italian in a homey atmosphere. Note that it is a little loud inside, and tables are close together. I'd recommend and visit again on a future Chicago visit.

Overall, excellent Italian food.  I went here with a work group and the food was delicious with large portions (great for eating later!).  The service was a little slow that night but overall very helpful and friendly. I like how this place has a discrete exterior.  The atmosphere here is very warm.  Check it out!
just like in new york city(all 5 boros) it was the best meal we had on our six nights there.. the food was excellent,the best italian food outside nyc...(like always,its my opin )

Fantastic Food.  Terrible Service. I ate here last night with two friends and had the calamari to start, which was fine, and ordered the gnocchi with salmonata sauce.  I actually was craving lasagna or manicotti, but their selection of vegetarian dishes was quite limited - mostly to the pick-a-pasta-and-sauce section of the menu. The gnocchi was delicious and the salmonata sauce was amazing, except for the numerous bones I found in the salmon.  But the portion was quite generous and I do love me some tomato cream sauce. But OMG the service was so baaaaaaaad.  I had to flag down the waitress and the guy helping with bread and drinks all three times I wanted a refill of my iced tea.  It also took a long time for the entrees to get out to us.  And the tables were crammed so close together that it was difficult to ignore the conversations of neighboring tables. I would probably go here again but might get the food to-go.  Delicious, but annoying.

I've been here several times, both for lunch and dinner, and each time is better than the last. The dishes are truly amazing and the service is some of the best in this city...and it's always consistent.  My husband and I had the debate last night of what our favorite Italian restaurant is in the city and this definitely tops it for me. The quality in their food is always so great and so fresh - and there isn't a thing on the menu that I have tried and didn't love.  One night I went and their special was a Fruiti Demare - which is scallops, clams, shrimp and mussels in a red sauce - and it was probably the best I've ever had. This is one of my favorite Italian dishes, and have tried it at a lot of places, but by far Volare's version of the dish is in the top 5. I also love their Grilled Seafood salad and their Calamari is also quite delish (especially with their amazing marinara sauce).  One of my favorite things about this place is you can choose your own type of pasta (orrechiette, farfalle, spaghetti, etc) and you pair it with whatever sauce you want....Pesto, Arrabiata, Bologne, Pomodoro, etc. It's really catered to be made the way you want it to be. If you go the pasta route I definitely recommend a side of Meatballs....they're truly some of the best I've had.

I used to live near this place and was complaining to one of my friends that there were no Italian restaurants in Chicago (I had moved from NYC) that made good vodka sauce.  She took me here and guaranteed I would like it.  I was skeptical at first but she proved she was right!  I have been there several times again since and now recommend this place to others too!  The only unfortunate thing is that there's no self parking - you have to try to find street parking, valet, or park in a lot, unless you live within walking distance or take a cab.

I had a great dinner and experience at Volare but I can't get over how touristy it feels there. I know it's supposed to be a sorta old-school Italian place but I didn't get that vibe. Our service was great and my meal (squid ink risotto w/calamari, shrimp, mussels & clams) was very tasty. I don't think many people would be disappointed here, but there are so many other Italian restaurants in town with much better atmosphere (Tuscany and La Scarola being my personal favs).

Having made a previous attempt to go to this restaurant on a Saturday night, but to no avail, I was most pleased when my Mum mentioned she fancied some Italian fare. It also helped that we'd had a few glasses of wine and this is stumbling distance to my place, so we could have another bottle.... but Volare gets 5 stars wherever it is.  The food was delicious. Down to the bread (warm focaccia and ciabatta with good olive oil). I had mussels in white wine and I will be returning for these - especially as their appetisers are easily enough to make a meal.  I wish I had read these previous reviews and knew that you could order half portions.. I have several pounds of clam linguine and chicken cacciatore languishing in my fridge, and I'm not sure I'll ever be able to finish them. It is not often - nay, ever - that my brother is defeated by food... but his bowl of gnocchi was a potato dumpling too far at about halfway through! All delicious. All drowned in oil, however, so if that's not your thing... go elsewhere. I didn't see anything that wasn't heavy on the oil and parmesan. Yum say I. Seriously, this is one of those most delicious meals I've had since moving here.  I'd recommend the patio. The inside is ridiculously noisy. I don't know how people were holding conversations in there; too much atmosphere for me. But the patio is lovely, and the service was attentive and speedy in both places as far as I could tell.  I'd give n extra star if I could because: THEY HAVE DECENT COFFEE! Super strong Italian espresso, made right.  So, in conclusion: order a glass of Montepulciano, have the mussels, share some pasta, and savour the coffee.

I've been wanting to try this place for a long but it's not in the most convenient spot for us.  But on sunday we managed to be near here and found a great parking spot so we popped in for lunch.  I love that they give you the option to do a half order for a few bucks less.  I can never finish my heaping bowls of pasta so I was all over this.  I had the rigatoni in vodka sauce and the husband had the bolognese...both were really good.  The outdoor patio is nice and I'm always a fan of a big bowl of warm bread. I'll be back  for dinner to try out some of the apps and wine.

This restaurant was fair. Food was good. Not amazing. The Gnocci in vodka sauce was indeed quite good but not so much the lobster ravioli that was on special or anything else for that matter.  Cramped restaurant, tablecloth was wet when we sat down and kept rubbing on my roommate's leg so she ended up moving as we don't typically enjoy wet cloth from who knows what touching our skin.  It also was her birthday which we notified the waiter of and he brought out a beautiful (and i will say yummy!!) piece of tiramusu with fruit around it and a candle, only to charge us ten bucks for it in our bill!  Eh, mediocre restaurant. Nothing to rave about.

Tasty and reasonable. How great is that? Plus you can literally order anything even if it's not on the menu. I always order the seafood pasta in a red sauce even though it's never on the menu and the chef always accomodates.  Not only that but it's one of my fave dishes in all of Chicago.   It's really great!  You won't be disappointed.  Note: Sitting outside is a little more exciting than inside. Inside is a little drab. They definitely need to hire an interior designer. But then again I'm not there for the not-so-fancy decor, I'm there for the tasty authentic italian food! Yum!

Hands down the best italian restaurante there is!  Two dishes that can't be beat here.  One and the dish that you must always try is the risotto!  The chicken and peas is the best one and trust me I've tried everyone possible.  Never was able to find anything comparable...Its the best!  I purposely go to this place probably a handful of times a year bc I truly never want to get sick of this place.  Its almost like my lil treat every other month.  Well 2nd but almost right up there is there mouth watering vodka sauce.  You can throw this sauce on any type of pasta you want.  Torts are great!  I would recommend this sauce w/ some peas and cheese torts.  I know it sounds like I love the peas but for some reason they just go the best w/ these two dishes.  I feel like homer simpson drooling over beer.  I think it goes like Arrrggghh BEER!  haha...Ok seriously hit me up if you think of a place differently bc im standing behind this restaurtant as #1 Italian.  Also kinda awkward about this place but ive seen the same workers here for years and you know the wait staff is pretty decent for as busy as they are, when they actually recognize you.  So many times ive been in there and wait staff, even the manager has recognized me saying you are back again.  Place does get a lil busy at times.....Best italian in Chicago!  Call me crazy!  :)

Very disappointing.  Loud, crowded and very poor service.  Food was reasonably good (once we finally had our correct entrees - a three ring circus of flying replacement meals as our server (who looked out the window while telling us the specials and never really did make eye contact during the evening)) tried to figure out why none of us wanted the osso bucco that none of us had ordered.  Last entree showed up about five minutes after the one before it.  Clearly in a rush to get us out so they could turn the table.  Which worked out well, since we couldn't wait to get out.

Thank you fellow yelpers!  You did not let me down! My boyfriend's dad and sister are in town and wanted to go to dinner tonight.  They asked me for a recommendation for good Italian... and having to pick out the restaurant is usually a panic-inducing situation for me.  Yelp to the rescue! Volare's reviews seemed solid, and the location perfectly near their hotel, so I went with it.  Was easy to get a reservation, we were seated immediately when we arrived at 6 (think this was before the usual dinner rush) and had great service. Someone mentioned the waiters' accents, and yes, they're very thick.   But the service is great, the portions are large, and it was a very nice dinner.  Had the appetizer special (a fresh antipasta) as well as the pasta special (with ground sausage, peas and mushrooms in a tomato sauce with fresh mozarella).  Pasta was homemade and everything was fresh. Thank you yelpers! Update: leftovers were delicious!

I recently had a very good dining experience here. My friend and I wondered in off the street looking for food....we were starving. We got here at about 10:59 on a Saturday night and didn't realize they close at 11. Even so they were able to seat us and feed us. Bless their hearts.  The food was fantastic. We were really in the mood for pasta so I had the linguini with the vodka sauce. It was really good, the sauce wasn't too rich which it sometimes can be. The portions are HUGE, I was able to make a big dent in it, but still had enough pasta to take home. I definitely recommend this place, they have a relaxed attitude with awesome food!!!!

After a long day spent escaping Buffalo, I'm checking into my hotel in Chicago and realized I was incredibly hungry.  I asked the woman at the Embassy check-in counter what she recommended around the area to eat.  This was her first suggestion, and I completely understand it. I'm not wholly sure what real 'home-style' cooking is, but I'm willing to consider that Volare might be it.  They had some of the best Italian food I've eaten.  I'm no expert on it, and I might have been biased because I was so hungry, but this stuff was incredible.  I ordered the paradelle bolognese (nothing fancy, again, I was just starving).  Before that even came out, however, they brought me the best bread I've ever had in my life.  I realize I'm one of the few people in the world with strong opinions on bread and toast, but I will tell you; the baker at Volare is unbelievably good at his or her job.  It was perfectly crusty on the outside and then warm and airy on the inside.  It was the perfect match for soaking up the remnants of the wonderful bolognese sauce that was left after I devoured the entire heaping portion. All in all, a wonderfully lucky find.  This is what you get when you ask locals where they go to eat. And also when you're smart enough not to eat at any hotel restaurant.

I was expecting more.  Our waiter recommended the gnocci with the ham and peas sauce, and I also had some fettuccine with vodka sauce.  Both were average, the sauces were a little too rich and salty, and that's coming from someone who loves salt.  It's the kind of stuff that will send you looking for a nice spot to pass out after chugging a big glass of water.  The bread was ok -- similar to Pompeii's.  Our waiter had an attitude, which got annoying.  Everyone else seemed nice though. The prices aren't bad, the sizes are decently big, and the food is ok.  Not that special.

This is one of my favorite italian spots in Chicago. Extremely casual with excellent food and good service. Also, it's very important to me that I do not feel rushed when enjoying a great meal, and they did not rush us at all despite it being a busy friday night. I can't wait to go back!

This place is amazing.  I took my grandfather here (born in Italy) and he loved the food and found it to be very authentic.  The homemade pastas are heaven and reasonably priced.  We had a big group, so the waiter offered to bring an appetizer platter.  It was great- fresh italian meats, jumbo shrimp cocktail, calamari among other things.  The table was impressed.  There are 2 things keeping this place from 5 stars: 1) rude hostess; our table was not ready for at least 20 minutes after our reservation and there was no apology, just a rude attitude  2) very loud, I would suggest only going in small groups to this place bc you can only hear the person sitting directly next to you

As a Bostonian spoiled by North End establishments, I was still impressed.  Our first night in Chicago, we were looking for a later-ish dinner on a Sunday night close to the Conrad.  We asked the conceriege for something in the vicinity and this place was suggested.  We called and were able to get a reservation an hour or so before.  We got there and it was packed!  We still didn't wait long, and we ended up with a seat outside, which was a plus.  My boyfriend got a Ceasar salad and I got the Caprese salad- divine.  Bread was ok- nothing special.  We got the chicken parm and the chicken vesuvio.  It was excellent!  Our waiter was good, too.  I give this place two thumbs up, especially for the reasonable prices.  However, as satisfied as we were, we also dined at RoSal's a few nights later... need I say more?
Very tasty authentic Italian food. The staff is very attentive like a family environment. It was loud but managable. We'd eat here again if in Chicago.

I'm a little hesitant to post this review because I love this restaurant so much and I don't want everyone in Streeterville horning in on our lunch spot.  On the other hand, Volare deserves all five stars, so here it is. Volare is where we go for lunch in the summer when we want a great salad.  I know, you're like, "salad?  What of it?"  I say to you: Volare Salad!  It's a delicious combination of lettuce, carrots, hearts of palm, marinated artichoke hearts (amazing!), fresh mozzarella, radishes, broccoli, and an awesome italian dressing.  No, it's not low fat.  Yes, it is delicious.   The best thing about lunch here is that you can get half orders of everything.  So, what I typically do is get a half Volare Salad and a half order of penne with vodka sauce (don't get me started!).  That's a nice lunch - and it's only about $1 more than Pockets for waiter service and much better food.   Yes, Volare - keep it up!

I didn't find anything that special about the place.  Food was okay, but average.  I often look to waiters for menu advice.  Hmmm wish I had just gone with a basic pasta dish -- was much more flavorful than the meat dish I was 'sold' on. The gnocchi was amazing. Saturday night was packed -- even with reso's we waited half hour.  There really is no where to wait. Waiters are old school, which certainly has it's charm.  Not much to speak of for ambiance.

This might be my favorite Italian restaurant in Chicago, and I realize that's a bold statement. I started going to Volare years ago since it's very conveniently located to my office. At one point I had to take a break from this restaurant because I was going at least once a week and I didn't want to OD on it. After taking a step back I can safely say that Volare and I now have a healthy relationship.  Their lasagna is AMAZING. Seriously, everything about it is divine. The pasta, sauce, meat, cheese...it's all gooey and heavenly. They also have a solid Caesar salad that is a good starter to any meal. And let me tell you about their vodka sauce...you could put that on anything and I'd eat it.  The restaurant itself is small and snug fit for everyone that wants to dine here. However, I've never had to wait more than 10 minutes for a table and that's rare. They have an outdoor patio that's shaded and let's enjoy the weather (when that's possible). The staff all have pretty heavy accents and it's sometimes difficult to understand them, but I just smile while I nod and they've never done me wrong.  I've been here many times for lunch with coworkers (they have lunch portions which is a nice option if you're not in the mood to beast out), it's a great option for a date, or if you're looking for a restaurant in River North that isn't a chain or crawling with tourists.

This is the place I've been looking for. Excellent italian food.  Not pretentious at all.  Friendly, prompt service.  Not too pricey. There were all different kinds of people here.  Some were dressed a bit fancy, some were dressed down.  I didn't feel out of place at all wearing jeans.  Good ambiance - appropriate for a date, dinner with friends/family, or for a business meal.  The service was great.  We never felt neglected or rushed.  The menu is pretty simple, but you can pretty much get any italian staple that you'd expect.  The food was fantastic, and I'm looking forward to going back and trying a few more things from the menu.  All around perfect for just about any occasion. On the way out, the manager (I presume) thanked us kindly.  It's nice to know that these smaller places exist where it just feels like they care a lot about you enjoying your experience.

for my one night in chicago i didn't stray too far from the W Lakeshore and we needed a bit of old school italian to keep us full. Volare was packed on a thursday night. The calamari and seafood salad were both surprisingly good. Pasta is average - large portions for a midwest size appetite.

I'll keep this short and sweet. If you go here, order the Gnoccis with vodka sauce. The pesto sauce is way too "pesto-y." Also, the bread is only "meh." But the gnocci with vodka sauce is killer. Enjoy!

I had a heart attack after eating here. Oh my.  I came here with my mom after work one day and the place is cute. Outdoor and indoor seating. There weren't many people there yet but they still decided to push everyone in one section against the wall. Our server had a very heavy accent and really couldn't understand a word she was saying.  I ordered ravoli is olive oil sauce...or something and I swear I have a clot now. This thing was just greasy and oiley and I cant even explain it. I couldn't finish it. It was beyond fatty.  The bathrooms are gross. Although the setup and decor is nice, its small and right by the kitchen. Is that even sanitary? The bathroom was dirty and smelled. Gross. It took us a long time to get our check and we were trying to get the hell out of there.  I dont recommend this place.

Had to wait about 10 minutes for our reservation for two, place was packed.  Didn't matter though because it was worth the wait.  Waitress was great!   Couldn't figure out if the Italian accent was real or not :) but it just added to the old school feel.  Had the mussels which were awesome...fresh muscles, in amazing spicy tomato sauce that had sauteed onions!  This place gets 5 stars from me because not only were the mussels some of the best I've had but the Scaloppine all Pizzaiola (Veal medallions sauteed with fresh tomatoes, oregano, capers, anchovies and white wine) was unbelievable...love capers!  Best Veal I've ever had!

Oh how I wanted to love you- went here about a month ago and have to say I wasn't in-love- would I comeback, yea, but would I seek it out- no.  Started off with the shrimp cocktail which was great, but maybe because it was toward the end of the night that I was there or what, but the cocktail sauce was so blah- now to dinner- a friend and i split some pasta and chicken parm.  Both were done nicely- sauce had a good flavor and not overly sweet. why do you not  get 4 stars? your service was so blah- our  waitress disappeared for what seemed forever...Also,  you do not get another star because you are so, so, so cramped inside- loose some tables- if you're around, check it out- but don't go out of your way

What a lovely outdoor patio! Most of the day, the sun won't even be in your face. We went here for lunch on a Saturday and were seated promptly.  The wait staff was very attentive and I thought the pre-meal bread was definitely worth the calories. We started with house salads with a well balanced vinaigrette. My SO ordered the special veal skirt steak with potatoes and arugula greens - I don't normally go for veal, but it was fantastic. I ordered an organic pasta with tomato sauce, sausage, peas, and mushrooms and it was also fantastic. Plus, paying lunch prices, you can't really get better than that.  There's not much more I can say about it, it was a very good meal in a quaint atmosphere and I'd definitely go back for dinner if I was in the area.

I like this place. But I think I like the outdoor patio more than the food. But the food is good, but not amaaaazing. It's pretty low key and quiet, which is really nice. I like coming here for lunch when it's nice out, but my co-workers don't seem to like it as much as I do!

An average Italian place.  Was very busy on a Saturday night and we were squished into a table with 8 people; BUT overall a good experience!  Good wine, good salads, and the entrees were pretty good!  I had the stuffed flank steak - which was a little on the dry side but overall good.  I had the opportunity to also try two of the risottos - the mushroom with red sauce:  good, the pea risotto with white sauce:  not so good.   Recommended.

I was so hungry I could have eaten an octopus...so I did, at least an entire plate of calamari (is calamari octopus, or squid...I forget). I then proceeded to sample everything they brought to our table. This place was great. Our numbers kept increasing, and they accomodated us. I ordered family style for the whole table and they didn't miss a beat.  With close to 30 of us, and a packed dining room, I expected a long wait for our food. We had barely finished placing our order, and the appetizers were on the table. Two Thumbs Up!

This was place is simply awesome.  It was totally jam packed at 8:30 on a friday night.  I had to fight just to get a seat the bar.  It was worth the 25 minute wait for a seat, was filled with fun people to talk to, and the vodka sauce was quite good.  Service was definitely slow and overwelmed with the number of people which is why I just can't give it five stars.
Hearty, lively and evidently super Tuscan.

This place is inconsistent. Some items are quite good while others don't measure up to expectations. First of all, the olive oil offered for dipping is bland, I wouldn't be surprised it is was just virgin instead of extra virgin. A hint: if you're using low quality olive oil, infuse it with something. I went there in a big group, so we had a lot to sample. I had the veal in a lemon white wine sauce. This was by far the best item on the table. It was quite good. Kudos. Two people got the caccitore, it was just OK. I can make better at home. The sweet sausage and peppers was decent. In short, some things are good and some are not... no consistency, and at a restaurant that charges these prices, that's unacceptable.

Volare, how do I love thee? Let me count the ways. I've been to Volare probably a half-dozen times between lunch and dinner and I've never been disappointed. Although I primarily go for a simple pasta entree, it always delivers in taste, texture and value. The restaurant can get quite busy at times, but the wait staff is professional and courteous. This might not be a bad place for a date, but can be both noisy and crowded, rather than "cozy". They have outdoor seating in the warmer months and I would highly recommend taking advantage of that. Additionally, it seems very popular for business lunches. Overall, I always recommend this venue for a high-quality Italian meal.

Just a minor update: the chicken parmasean was super tasty, and it does come with a side of pasta. I originally thought it didn't. The chicken itself was good enough for two people or leftovers (or as I like to say "food for tomorrow").  Looking for something lighter? Try the salmon with a side of spinach. I was stuffed right away and thought the portions were just enough. I feel bad for passing up the dessert both times I was here....but I just can't take another bite.

This place can get quite busy as times, which isn't so surprising given its size, but it is SO worth being patient!  I cannot rave enough about the tomato vodka mascarpone penne pasta.  I've not found a place that either makes this sauce  -- my server at Maggiano's even claimed that it would be "too sweet" when I inquired, which is odd on further reflection because he wasn't the chef -- or can do it as well (thanks Francesca's Forno, you came pretty close and I appreciated the effort).  Other than the vodka sauce, the appetizers were all consistently good and the service was attentive despite having a full house of diners.

Not so friendly host staff, very friendly waiter.  Went back with a Volare regular and she did not disappoint. Mussels - spicy and excellent Gnocchi - awesome, topped with (upon requests) bolognese done spicy (like the arrabbiata) Chicken cacciatore - impressive Breaded veal parm - only dish that was a little subpar. But Volare's tiramisu was the absolute best tiramisu I've tasted in a long time.  Another bulletproof recession-proof establishment.

Food is really good.  All the pasta dishes seem pretty authentic.  My favorite is the Arrabbiata sauce.  The home-made gnocchi are really good too.  The food gets four stars.  The service is pretty good too.  I've been there a a few times and it's always been really busy. But our food was still brought to us in a decent time frame.  I will say that this is not a really fun place to eat.  The setting is  nothing special-- loud, cramped, boring.

Talk about a friendly Chicago establishment! That's right, establishment - Volare has obviously been around for years and for good reason. Nothing about it is trendy. The restaurant is in a small building in the shadow of the Mag Mile. When you walk in you see the kitchen on your right (looks like it came from a 1950's diner) and the single open dining room on the left. During my visit I was greeted by literally every staffer in the restaurant, both at arrival and departure. Our server was outstanding - he was cordial, provided just the right amount of attention, and made fine service look easy. That's what earned Volare its fifth star in my opinion. Food was outstanding - I don't often seek out "plain old" Italian but when I do I will go here. Volare has a full, authentic menu and is great at what it does. Everyone says try the vodka sauce... I couldn't resist the Alfredo, myself, so I guess I will have to go back!

I have been here twice and have not been terribly impressed either time. The first time I went the food was okay. I just had a basic spaghetti. However, the second time I went we had a party of 4, with a reservation. We had to wait over an hour to get a table, with a reservation!! That is absolutely crazy. I then proceeded to order pasta with pesto sauce. The sauce was really awful tasting and everyone else at the table agreed. I should have sent it back, but the waitress was already being pretty rude and I didn't want to deal with it. In retrospect, I really should have sent it back because it was horrible.

Minus one star after another visit here...we made reservations and still had to wait almost 30 minutes for a table! Our coats were taken to some mysterious basement without being tagged with a number, and it was like a wild goose chase trying to get reunited after our meal. Food was fab as always but really, Volare either needs to cut down on the number of tables it has in its building or spring for a larger building. It's way too crowded, and I'm sure that we'd all die a fiery death if a flame was ignited in here.

I had pretty high hopes for Volare after reading so many good reviews, but I didn't think it was anything too special. The food was good, but nothing outstanding. The menu didn't have any standout selections, but daily specials are offered.  My friend and I started with a caprese salad and it was nice that even though it was January the tomatoes were fresh. We split an order of gnocchi with vodka cream sauce and that is the only food I remember. But and Italian restaurant SHOULD make good gnocchi. After that we also split the fish special which was sea bass and it was okay. Foodwise, I'd go back but I'm not craving anything from here. I do have a BIT of a problem with the service. The waitress was playing some games with our bill. My friend and I split the tab so I put down my share in cash (half plus more for tip) and we wanted the balance on my friends credit card. Instead of doing as we asked, the waitress charged the same amount on the credit card as the cash was down. So she basically gave herself a tip! And also, if we weren't paying attention we could have tipped on top of that. So we took some cash backk and she got less of a tip for messing around like that. But it seems pretty popular. We got to dinner at 5:30 and there was plenty of room but by the time we were finished at 7pm people were crashing into our table trying to squeeze by in teh packed dining room.

This is one of the best Italian restaurants in the Chicagoland area.  Not a franchise, family owned and operated.  Quality and freshness sums up the menu here.  The four cheese risotto is POWER.  Great fish dishes.  The sauces are all homemade and tasteful.  Chicken parm is POWER.  Great selection of wines and desserts.  The waitstaff is always attentive and helping.

Best italian food in the city... Everything tastes fresh, I've never been disappointed with anything I've eaten here.  Are there some minuses sure, its noisy, always crowded and they don't handle reservations very well- expect to wait 20-30 minutes on the weekends even if you have one. *Always make a reservation when going there, its always, always packed and the place is tiny.  So if you can get past the noise level, the bad italian euro-pop playing in the background and long waits, you won't be sorry because you will be in for a good meal.

This is old school at its best.  The decor is classy and conservative.  The menu isn't adventurous but it offers a very solid representation of Italian cuisine.  Most of the pasta is dried, but there are a few house-made pastas to choose from.  I ordered the lasagna Bolognese and was very satisfied.  My dinner partner ordered the Pollo Cacciatore and the chicken was perfectly cooked and the sauce was tasty and bold.  We shared a Caesar Salad and I would've preferred a little bit more anchovy but I know I'm usually in the minority in this request.  We did not order dessert but they looked appetizing and I would certainly not hesitate to order one if I hadn't eaten so much!  The service was very good.

If you want the freshest, biggest, most succulent pieces of ANY seafood in the city, this is the place to go.  The seating is tight yes, but the staff maneuvers quite well around you.  Not a bother at all. The food is so great and I salivate over the seafood. Just amazing!!

Oh Volare, you disappoint me.  The good: - The rigatoni alla vodka, like everyone else has said, was very good (and only 10 bucks) - The greeting...we were asked by four different people if we had been helped The bad:  - The foccacia in the bread basket was stale - The minestrone soup was full of those vegetables that you buy in a bag in the freezer section that my mom used to try to pass off as actual vegetables at dinner - Service was nonexistent except for the basics--drop off menus, take order, foodrunner brings order, bussers clear plates, drop off check, pick up check. Our server failed to greet us or introduce herself but rather came by and said only, "What can I get you to drink?" - The tables are way too close together  - It was extremely loud during the lunch hour and made it very difficult to converse The ugly: - I have been vomiting for the past two hours. Not pointing fingers, but the only other things I have consumed in the past 24 hours are coffee and wheat thins I am giving two stars because the pasta was very good and despite getting sick I would probably give the place another try, though this time for carry out. Vomiting aside, the atmosphere and service at Volare were completely disappointing. I'm embarrassed to have taken a client here and certainly hope that he isn't puking his guts out too.

I have found a slice of heaven, and it is called Volare's ricotta cheesecake. I am still drooling just a little bit merely writing this review. I like this place, as it is always bustling, but that does not detract from their attentiveness and food quality. Probably not the most romantic of venues for a date, but their lunch and dinner crowd are devoted for a reason. My friends and I split the calimari and beef carpaccio appetizers, and I had the grilled salmon with a lemon-caper-white wine sauce for an entree.  The icing on the cake, though, was the cheesecake. You must try!!

We ended up going here because it was nearby and quite cold out.  This is pretty much an old school red sauce sort of place.  The calamari we started with was a little bland and came with something that resembled cocktail sauce (Weird.)  The pasta arrabiatta we had was pretty good and the wait staff was attentive enough.  In short, a decent choice if you're in the neighborhood, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go there.

I live in the neighborhood so we get take out from them when we are too lazy to go out for Italian food.  I love love their risotto de volare which is basically a seafood risotto.  The risotto rice is cooked in the squid ink, and a big pile of seafood comes in the middle, calamari, shrimp, scallop, mussels, clams.  I have not been successful in diverging from the risotto yet.  Sorry.

I was planning to visit Chicago with my family and was looking for a restaurant downtown that was authentic Italian and was family friendly.  I got referred to Volare off Yelp and my entire family loved the evening.  We will definitely be back for another great evening.
